review_title: This company needs to improve the way it handles women leaders - now!
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Milpitas, CA
pros: Opportunities to manage large teams and complex problems. This company does very interesting engineering work.
cons:
Female engineering leaders are consistently discriminated against in this company. I know several woman engineering managers who complain of being over-loaded, under-leveled, and under-paid as compared to their male counterparts in the same org, doing exactly the same work, and sometimes even having a larger team. I know several anecdotes of male senior managers engaging in gender-discriminatory behavior & comments when it comes to compensation, growth, acknowledging achievements, and providing actionable feedback.
Instead of supporting women in leadership and encouraging growth, Cisco is consistently burning woman leaders out. Go ahead and count the number of women who are at least one-level skip managers in an engineering team in Cisco. Hint - you may be able to count them on your fingertips.

review_title: Perhaps the best large tech company out there!
job_title: Senior Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Extremely competent and driven management team.  Excellent communication top down from the CEO through the leadership teams to the general teams.  
Good salary structure and general (non-salary) rewards & recognition.  
John Chambers genuinely cares what employees are thinking and feeling.
People are truly empowered to make a difference, and encouraged to do so.
Great flexibility in terms of schedules.
cons:
Incredible hours and extremely high expectations.  Expect to multi-task to the nth degree.
No cost of living adjustments and the vast majority of compensation benefits (increases, etc) seem to go to a limited set of top performers.  If & when you are in the top percentages you are treated very well.

As a large company it can be very hard to negotiate, and it can be political.

review_title: Glad I came here, looking forward to the journey
job_title: Sales Account Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: In this market, having a product that saves companies money makes it easier sell. Also they are open to ideas from junior folks as well as senior. Being now under Cisco means its like working for a smaller company at Webex but with the great benefits of a bigger company like Cisco. I like how they are customer first and Cisco takes care of their folks and community.
cons: I'd like to telcommute a day a week and that seems discouraged which is funny as we work for WebEx. They are struggling a little with Cisco alignment with territories but glad to see they are discussing it and making changes where necessary.

review_title: A good company to work for; but still with some challenges to overcome
job_title: Service Delivery in Washington, DC
pros:
- A large technology company with a large breadth of technology areas and market coverage should provide varied opportunities for growth
- Great place for people with outstanding technical backgrounds who are looking to be challenged
- Surprising amount of room for growth even though it is currently a large company
cons:
- Challenges exist for people who join and do not have detailed technical skills.  Cisco struggles with how to use and take full advantage of non-technical resources such as Program Management
- HR processes (career and professional development) not well managed

review_title: Reputation for mediocre workforce
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco is indeed the power player for switches, routers, and networking.  There are usually opportunities for WFH, the helath club is great, medical facility/optometrist/dry cleaner all onsite, and a healthy work/life balance is encouraged.
cons: The company is so big that almost nothing said about it can be applied across the board, from its internal culture to management style, as most of the organizations within the company operate under different levels of Exec VPs, Senior VPs, or regular VPs...  The only company-wide criteria applicable to the whole company is probably HR and IT, which are totally self-serve.  If you are working at Cisco, there will not be an admin to do your busy work or a number you can call to have someone "take care of that."

review_title: Good, with room for improvement
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Bangalore
pros: good exposure into various clients. Flexible work hours, no one cares where you work from as long as you are doing your work to the satisfaction of your managers, field engineers and clients. compensation was good, and so were other benefits. Very employee friendly. certifications and continued learning.
cons: Some of the teams in India were more back end. Even with client relationships, you would be doing work that the Field engineers were not interested in doing. It was cost effective for you to be doing the work. Not easy to shift teams. If you get stuck in some of the teams from which you wanted to shift, it would take a long time. There is no internal mechanism to rotate or provide opportunity for people to explore other roles within the company.

review_title: Great Job---but....
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Great Pay, Industry leader, great benefits, great autonomy and world class people...you are working with the key people in the industry....you are a leader...you are driven and love it....plenty of off sites, volunteer events....you will learn more and drive major initiatives...a truly great job..
cons: Be careful of believing in your own propaganda.  they boast of the business unit and then lay off 40%....there are great leaders...and there are weak ones...and the weak ones will do anything to stay on...and they will ask for your thoughts...but really do not want them...agree with them or leave.  This company will reorg and layoff every quarter...and then hire on new grads to replace the seniors....a great experience comes with severe issues.  I saw the best mangers...and the worst at one company--and there is a bit of a loyalty issues from those managers.

review_title: If You Value People Over Money, Cisco is Top of Class
job_title: Human Resources Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Amazing opportunities to learn different things, technologies, industries. If you enjoy twisting and turning your way through the day and jumping through hoops to make things happen, you'll enjoy Cisco. If you appreciate different challenges and continuous change, you'll enjoy Cisco. If you like consistency and a slower pace, you'll struggle to keep up. If you value leadership and the idea of learning from others as an early in career employee is important to you (over pay) then you'll enjoy Cisco.
cons: You won't make a million dollars in your first 10 years ... it might take 20. Pay, and promotional velocity aren't amazing, but you'll never have to worry about getting the things you need.

review_title: Culture has been replaced.
job_title: Solution Architect in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
I work in Cisco Security services,  and the last 2 years have been horrible.    This used to be a great company and great culture.  The last 2 years over,  great caring and capable managers have been replaced with newbies who operate without a care for employees and in lockstep with the new senior management.

Sadly,  much of the senior management is now from places like Pepsi and sourcefire.  These senior folks are dishonest, calculating and manipulative.   They also have super fragile egos and fire people for simply knowing more than they do.
cons: Having Cisco on your resume used to be a huge strength.  But nowadays it's becoming a liability in the job market.   That combined with the annual summer picnic and layoff,  it's become a truly bad place to work.

review_title: Global company. Genius coworkers. Limitless opportunities
job_title: Customer Support Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Overall, Cisco is a pretty great place to work!
-Great benefits like stock options, cheap health insurance, volunteering time off and donation matching, remote work options, the list goes on.
-Endless learning and job opportunities. Ability for stretch assignments to try other job roles or locations. Emphasis on self training and certifications to help further your career.
-Work with some of the smartest people in the industry. Great mentorship programs to learn from the best and get career advice.
-Leadership and executives that are receptive to change, new ideas and transparency.
cons:
-Big company. A bit overwhelming at times. Can be hard to find resources or people necessary to perform your job.
-Annual layoffs without an emphasis on retraining current talent.

review_title: State of the art campus, cutting edge hardware design activities and good work-life balance guaranteed
job_title: Manager, Hardware Eng in Bangalore
pros: Nobody tells you where to draw the line or what not to do, as long as you get the job done. You will have sufficient time to explore any relevant technology and get your hands dirty. Cisco Bangalore has state of the art lab facilities, ample and regular in house training options. From hardware design standpoint, we are given opportunities on par with what happens at San Jose, maybe with a 1-2Q delay but good work does eventually reach our shores.  The management is transparent top down and recognitions are promptly awarded where due. Pay is on merit and merit is greatly valued with limited scope for internal politics and cronyism. Overall, a great place to be in.
cons: Sometimes you will doubt hardware's relevance in Cisco's long term 'No.1 IT company' strategy.  Market dynamics change pretty fast, especially in the Service Provider world.

review_title: Great culture & work/life balance
job_title: Virtual Sales Account Manager in Amsterdam
pros: Cisco has a great work culture. Employees are very helpful and care about each other. If you need help you can ask anyone. Very happy to have these colleagues, since a lot of my questions can be quickly answered due to the experience some others already have. Besides working hard, Cisco also makes sure that the work/life balance is good. They do this by organizing regularly drinks, parties and family events such as Sinterklaas and a summer BBQ.  Besides that we have a yearly sales event in Vegas, this truly shows that the management want to invest in us to keep up our knowledge and get excited for the new fiscal year.
cons: At the end of the quarter it can be very busy with regards to reaching your and your team's target.

review_title: 5 reasons why cisco employees are smiling
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: flexibility in work schedule, an actual career path and planning ensures growth, as an employee you can take advantage of all the programs, interest groups, organizations whose operations range from the larger corporate culture to a very personal level of your team -- given the opportunity to hone your development experience within a well managed process.  no matter what stage you are at in your career, you will always find yourself learning from someone - or you'll find bright, freshness, and motivation of youth that could use the mentoring of an experienced professional.  you can really live the 9-5 life and be fine, or if your bursting with that 'start-up' spirit, management will not hesitate to compensate and recognize your efforts.
cons: pay - known and admittedly so that top dollar isn't paid to it's employees.

review_title: Cisco is the best place to work for techies who still want a personal life
job_title: Technical Leader in Sydney
pros: Access to the best technical resources and people to do your job and learn. You get the opportunity to work hard and be rewarded for your efforts but there isn't so much pressure that you can't enjoy your family life. There is so much information and training on the internal cisco web that the thought of losing access once I leave cisco is quite upsetting. Anyone interested in computer networking much aim to work for cisco system.
cons: The HR department is a bit of a monster. I sometimes wonder if the marketing team is pitching something that is a bit fluffy and touchy feely to be appreciated by the people who actually buy and use our equipment.

review_title: Huge corporations are not for me
job_title: Software Engineer III in San Jose, CA
pros: Can live your own life without being bothered too much... Availability of internal training which would otherwise be very expensive. Very good medical benefits.
cons:
Cisco is just too big. Most of the people are career hungry, but there's little opportunity to grow for 99% of the people that are there. It's a mostly Indian company (in my team of 20, there were 18 indians) and they just work differently from most of the other American companies.

They try to put a lot of pressure on engineers; I thought a company like cisco would go for the "correct" solution rather than the quick hack. False.

In Cisco, staying at the office 10 hours is better (i.e. gives you more visibility) than staying at the office 8 hours and be REALLY productive. It's all about "cover your ass". Not my ideal job.

review_title: Very good company, culture, and people. Normal problems for a (very) large company.
job_title: Program Manager IV in Raleigh, NC
pros: Collaborative, smart, fun people. Work/life balance is respected and encouraged. Changing jobs internally is encouraged and necessary to prevent stagnation. World class benefits. Outstanding high level leadership, middle management less so.
cons: Too often there are simply too many people on projects and in meetings which hinders ownership, accountability, and progress. While pay is in line with industry and geographic location advancement and compensation increases are very hard to come by which is the nature of such a large organization. You can move around to different roles across the company fairly easily but that doesn't really translate to pay increases or promotions. Global nature of teams and work means meetings will cut into personal time. Company is highly San Jose centric - partly understandable but no less frustrating at times for those in remote locations.

review_title: A good company to work for
job_title: New Product Project Manager in Milpitas, CA
pros: A solid company that overall treats its employees well.  Good benefits, with ability to work from home every now and then.  A lot of smart and talented people, both in Development and in Supply Chain organizations.  Lots of challenging and interesting projects.  Employee recognition methods are changing for the better.
cons: For a new product that has not yet "proven" itself in the market, resources are often minimal, so people get spread pretty thin.  The hours can get long for long stretches of time.  The top management can sporadically change direction, and years' worth of work can go down the drain.  Cost-cutting has led to a lot of churn with contractors and off-shoring.

review_title: Partner Development Manager
job_title: Partner Account Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Amazing people and partners.  Good compensation and benefits.  Work from home allows good work life balance.  Although work is on 24/7
cons: No one is safe.  Annual and sometimes semi annual layoffs with no way to predict if your on the chopping block other than being over 40 and at the mid-top of your pay grade.  There is no loyalty anymore to its employees.  People put in 10-15-20 years and get a 30 min call with their manager and they are let go.  Gone are the days that John Chambers used to say that he wanted people to retire from Cisco... tell their kids and grandkids how they loved working at Cisco.  Now its all about the shareholders.

review_title: Definitely in flux, some good people on specific teams, below market salaries
job_title: Project Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: Specific teams have great people, I'm sure this is true of any company. Really good work-life balance since virtual culture was embraced long ago. Hiring from outside brings fresh perspectives.
cons: Lack of diversity, and a diversity office/leaders that has little idea of what it does but catch phrases that make it appear as if it's doing something. Should be entirely revamped with people who truly care about diverse workforces and perform. Ongoing policy of laying off an older workforce. It's sad to see great partners being let go over the past 4-5 years. Migrating internal technologies get launched too often, right when we get a grip on the one that was just launched.

review_title: Trying to be Great, but not Walking the Talk
job_title: Human Resources Consultant in Richardson, TX
pros:
- Good benefits that are constantly being updated to be best in the industry
- Compensation practices that encourage fair pay
- Autonomy in job
cons:
- Cisco says their leaders are transparent and "have your back," but leaders do not give feedback and won't help their employees progress in their careers.  
- All the acquisitions make Cisco a very segmented and unfair place.  Different treatment for many of our big acquisitions still exist and their is no timeline to create a 1 Cisco mentality.
- Management doesn't like the HR processes, systems, and tools created to make a transparent, listening, fair, and engaging environment so employees suffer.

review_title: Flexible, Great Benefits, Turbulent Change & Lots of Politics
job_title: Head of Marketing in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexible work hours and great ability for work/life balance. Excellent benefits and good salary across the board. Generally very good people to work with and good culture that gives back to the community.

Many egos and difficult people brought in to lead some groups - and then they lead by bringing in their people and playing favs. Also, you'll find Execs w/little Marketing experience w/big titles. Continued changes to Marketing team w/lots and lots of process. Multiple changes on-going and about every 3 years the entire model gets shaken up.  Disappointing that Chuck lets this all go on.

review_title: Used to be great
job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros: Great company with great products, strong senior leadership, excellent brand, opportunities to grow depending on how aggressive you are with your career, excellent sales teams, stable - lots of cash, great HQ location.
cons: Used to be nimble, fun place to work. But over the past 6 years, the company has taken on huge, multi-year business improvement projects that have created massive middle management that is incompetent, territorial, siloed, the result being millions of dollars are being spent with no proven result. Company spends millions on top management consultants for no conceivable return on investment. Too many boards and councils have made the company extremely slow. Great strategies but it is difficult to operationalize due to the incompetent management.

review_title: Cisco used to be a great place to work.
job_title: IT Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: There are a lot of different departments to transfer into if you don't like where you are or if you want to do something new.
cons:
Transfers are subject to many layers of management approval and are often stopped for arbitrary reasons or just plain spite.  It's also a good way for 'drones' to go and hide for a couple of years until the next group figures out they are just keeping the chairs warm.  

The Internal processes are archaic and only serve to slow down progress and keep the process people employed. A project that takes six months at any other company takes two years at Cisco.

Politics is by far the worst of any place I've ever seen. It's more about climbing the ladder and getting more power than doing the job.

review_title: not a good place for the young, smart, and ambitious
job_title: Software Engineer I in Milpitas, CA
pros:
It is a great place for older folks with families and mortgages. It's very stable and poor performance will not get you fired unless you are unbelievably bad (but there are exceptions to this as well).

For those with lack of internship experience, Cisco is a good place to pick up a skill set and move on to another company.
cons:
1. Career advancement is non-existent. 
2. No increases to salary to keep up with inflation.
3. Little recognition for good work.

review_title: Engineer's Review
job_title: Software Engineer I in San Jose, CA
pros:
Work life balance can be pretty decent if you want it to be. 
Overall compensation is on par.
Fringe benefits have been decreasing but are still there.
Very flexible work hours.
cons:
Your ability to succeed or fail at cisco depends heavily on the relationship you have with your direct manager and what he is willing to do for you. Many of the managers are great at cisco. The working relationship I shared with mine however was poor thereby making my time at cisco more difficult than average. In CA, lower level engineers have been converted to hourly salaries with decrease in compensation which is bad.

Cisco tends to breed incompetency and complacency on projects that have been around awhile, only innovating via acquisition. 

The direction they are taking in the consumer market seems very misguided.

review_title: Great place to work back in the day
job_title: Test Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Opportunity to develop market leading products.
Lots of smart peers.
Good benefits package.
"Blue chip" company.
Develop proficiency in Cisco product line.
cons:
Long hard hours. 
Can be frustrating to try and improve things.
Too much politics.

I've been reading the other reviews here. There seems to be two major complaints that stand out. One is lack of upward mobility or promotions, the other is the enlarged know-nothing middle management and lots of turf wars. These seem to be contradictory. Those that want better promotions... to where? So they can also be "useless" middle managers?  Technology companies need people that can actually build stuff. You can't be promoting everybody to management, there is not enough to manage. If you do, then you have the other complaint "too many managers". What is Senior management to do?

review_title: Big ideas but poor leadership
job_title: Business Analyst in Richardson, TX
pros: Cisco has great big ideas such as Internet of Things, become #1 IT company, video will drive bandwidth usage, etc. Cisco does great job of marketing the big ideas.
cons: Management has done a very poor job to engage employees.  This creates an environment where employees are not giving their best efforts to accomplish the big ideas.  Another major con is the lack of promotions.  Promotions just don't occur with any frequency.  Salary increases (just for cost of living) don't happen.  Also, there is a yearly workforce reduction that occurs.

review_title: HR project manager
job_title: Human Resources Project Manager in London, England
pros:
The people you get to work with here are amazing!!
Also, if you have an idea, all you need to do is to find a few more people who share your passion and just start working on it. You might be surprised where your project might take you. 
Great flexibility around where you are working from and when you do your work. 
Access to technology is great.
And Cisco is amazing at giving back to the community, really proud of what we can achieve together.

review_title: We make a profit, but sorry, RIF's are part of our culture
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA

review_title: It was better
job_title: Software Engineer IV in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Cisco is the Industry leader, and you get exposed to all the technologies needed.

The company is too big and each team is more concerned about short term budget and goals, rather than planning for the long run.

The idea of "getting fresh blood" and "restructuring" that pushed the experienced ones out (either voluntarily and involuntarily) is a big loss to Cisco's investment.

review_title: Low Compensation as per Bay Area Standard.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Good work life Balance.
A company from where you can retire.
cons:
Salaries & Compensation are not at par as Bay Area Standard may be it's a case only in IT software and not in engineering groups.

Every year is coming as a challenge, trying to innovate but nothing is working out, it's like stagnant, no scope to grow.

All interns work here for 2-3 years, learn, and then just find a better job with better compensation.

review_title: Great Company to Have a Work-Life Balance
job_title: Business Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: As someone early in their career, I've found that Cisco is a very welcoming environment. Individual contributors have the opportunity to work from home two days per week, and managers are very accommodating to working with occasional schedule conflicts. The benefits (401K employer-match, health insurance, PTO) are fantastic, and employees are also given the opportunity to earn Connected Recognition (awards via gift cards) for outstanding work. In addition to regular PTO, employee are given 40 hours of PTO per year designated to volunteering for the community, and Cisco will give $10 to the organization for every hour and employee volunteers. The cafeterias on campus are delicious and a great deal, and many of the floors in the buildings are being newly renovated. Overall, Cisco is a great place to work!
cons: It is a very large company, so you do have to work alongside people in other time zones via WebEx.

review_title: No Diversity in Engineering
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Benefits, great set of products and services. Compensation is ok,  could be improved in some of the engineering roles.  Can’t think of many other pros, trying to hit the 20 word minimum limit to be honest.
cons: No diversity in engineering. It’s operated as a compete sweatshop. Nights and weekends are normal working hours for some BUs. No advancement if you are not part of the same ethnic group.. You are replaced by someone who can work the extra hours and has the yes sir attitude. Contractors are flown in over a span of two days and stuffed into apartments with others to do sub par work for sub par pay.

review_title: Great company and great culture
job_title: Sales Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: Cisco supports diversity, excellent culture that feels like an extended family.  Growth potential.  Excellent benefits.  Highly competitive.  Very strong culture.  Nurtures groups for comradery (example Connected Black Professionals - CBP).   Work with some the best brightest minds.  Lots of training and personal development opportunities if you need/seek them.  Very socially responsible.  Great community giveback support and programs.
cons:
Operates on the cheap from a T&E perspective.  Not place where they help you chart your career path.  The opportunities are abound but you must take ownership of your career.

Would like to see more minorities in the senior leadership.  That said, Chuck, Chris and the likes have always made me feel that they are picking the best people for the leadership team.

review_title: Good Company, a Bit Politic, Lots of Great & Crummy Managers
job_title: IT Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Love the philanthropy and good hearts of many folks. Some great leadership like Guillermo and Rebecca. Chuck is doing some great things in a post-Chambers world. Good opportunities to move around within the company, but don't expect to move and get a promotion (there are hypocritical policies to prevent that). Great work life balance.
cons: Tenure based promotion system. Many managers take credit for their direct reports' work or efforts. WAY too much focus on outsourcing, which comes with monumental quality issues -- not sure how it got this bad, but management needs a lesson in balancing onshore and offshore; the answer cannot always be fire the onshore guy and replace him with 2.5 offshore guys who do worse work.

review_title: Great company to work for
job_title: Business Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: I've been at Cisco for over two years now and it has been a wonderful experience. My leadership has constantly encouraged and supported me to grow and challenge myself, and the people I work with generally also enjoy working here as well so it's easy to come into work every day. The hours are more flexible than other companies as long as you can manage your own work well which makes for a great work-life balance.
cons: Cisco is such a huge company and many times you are easily silo'ed in the organization that you are in and you do not really have a lot of opportunities to interact with other colleagues outside that. You can counteract this by joining plenty of interest groups however there seems to be a gap in communication at times between different orgs and different teams that would benefit well from better collaboration.

review_title: Network Consulting Engineer
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
Great Work culture . Flexible timings ( not applicable for some TAC engineers ). A lot of stress on learning ( Some BUs like CX have training sessions scheduled for the first 6 months and expect CCNA and CCNP from its engineers in this duration ) .
Starting salary is the same for all new hires regardless of college .
cons:
Salary is not on par with other companies of similar stature.
Huge intake . ~500 new grads every year which also means that there is not much growth opportunities for the first few years . 
Low/no hikes .
People hired for 2020  onwards have 14 lakh RSUs which was not given to previously hired employees.
Hire from a very few select colleges and hence the talent is not uniformly good .

review_title: Cisco Rocks Much More Than Not
job_title: Senior Integrated Marketing Communications Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexibility, Working with other smart people, stable company, caring company, opportunities to learn new things, opportunity to move around to get broader business experience, good benefits - especially the 401k matching, tuition reimbursement, work for an industry leader and visionary, great brand,
cons: if you don't set your boundaries this place will take everything you are willing to give it, increasing costs of medical benefits, not enough training and expectations for people managers in regards to their people management skills.

review_title: Me love Cisco long time
job_title: Strategist in San Jose, CA
pros: I am surrounded by smart people who are well intentioned. People feel like, not only are we doing good work here, but we are also doing something that has the potential to change the way people connect.  Innovating new ways to to interact with each other and our world is exciting.  Changing business models and being part of what's next is a great thing. I like coming to work almost every day.
cons: The campus environment is dated - WAY DATED!  It doesn't scream "CHANGE THE WORLD BY CREATING" -- it's more Dilbertesque.  Also, you have to be able to navigate a lot of ambiguity and be self directed or this place will be overwhelming.

review_title: Solid, stable company with great market share, and what you would expect from a DOW component.
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: The company enjoys the position as the leader in its market (networking) and has a strong portfolio of products to maintain that lead.  The culture is fairly open and transparent, and all levels of management focus on regular communication.  The company regularly adopts new technology especially as it utilizes its own products.
cons: As with any extremely large company, there is politics to deal with. The company strongly favors extroverts with a culture that tends to reward "talkers" far more than "doers".  The company has hit a position where growth has slowed, which means promotions are far more limited than at startups and other smaller companies.

review_title: Executive leadership (top 3-4 tiers) are indecisive, inconsistent and self-serving
job_title: Director in San Jose, CA
pros: Really smart people, and very cool technology. If the culture were better, they could make a significant difference in the world.
cons: Unwelcoming to leaders who join from the outside (unless you're from HP or IBM). Not OK to disagree with leadership - especially in front of others. Company pays lip service to caring about employees day-to-day - yes, they will help if your family gets sick, but they won't make it an easy, caring place to work. Hyper political culture, where if you aren't long time friends with (or related to) the main exec's, you will have a hard time building support for doing the job the company asked you to do. Don't trust what the managers tell you. They don't generally have the power to do what they say they will.

review_title: Top Heavy, Lack Strategy, Weak Leadership
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Flexible Work/Life balance
- Decent Benefits.  Medical, Time off, on site health care, fitness.
Decent Salary. Base salary + bonus for all employees.  Some get RSU.
-
cons:
- Senior leadership lacks technical acumen.  Most don't have a technical degree and many have not even come up the technical ranks.  How can you possibly have a engineering VP who has never been an engineer?
- Lots of off shoring of cool projects.  Watch out if you are engineer.  
- Promotions and ratings are based on who you know and not what you accomplish.
- They don't reward risk takers.  There is a lot of lip service to working on next gen projects.  But when things don't work out, they cut the working level staff.  Somehow they save the directors and VPs though and find them new roles... even though they are the ones who set the strategy!

review_title: Software Engineer
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Great work life balance : Great place to START and/or END your career at.
Great people.
Work from home  option can be exercised freely.
Decent benefits.
cons:
Perpetual organizational churn
Employees referred to as resources
No clear goals / targets (Talking about engineering depts here)
NO performance evaluation making it difficult to chart a growth course if you are beginning your career.

I think with all the Spin-In business Cisco forgot about internal organic growth.

review_title: Great company
job_title: Consulting Systems Engineer in London, England
pros: Great life work balance, can work from home and have all the tools to be as efficient as in the office, good benefit - including healthcare, dental, life insurance, stimulating work environment.
cons: The salary is not competitive compared to the industry average; for the past 5 years at the end of fiscal year (august / september) one has to worry about its job as they have been systematically reducing staff to align to the new corporate strategies. Let's be clear about this, we are not talking of letting go the bottom x%, here we are talking of cutting whole departments of the organisations that are no longer aligned to the company ever changing vision.

review_title: Customer focus is king at Cisco
job_title: Customer Success Manager in Zürich
pros: Cisco is truly about "customer first" so you don't waste time and energy for internal fights or administrative nightmares, people and management style is driven by self-empowerment,  Cisco has great agile work culture and teaming, people really want to help each other, at Cisco you enjoy a world-class workspace and unique technology available to everyone which make working in a truly global company such a great experience, home-office is just normal since ever, which gives a fantastic level of flexibility for your daily work. You can do what you believe is the right thing to do.
cons: constant change and self organisation can be challenging at some times.  You constantly have re-shape your job role, which can be sometimes a bit overwhelming.

review_title: Great place to work if you want the right mix of life and work.
job_title: Software Engineer II in San Jose, CA
pros: Excellent salary package, great work culture, great technology, flexible timings. I don't have much idea about the stock options, but the stock is pretty flat now, so don't know whether people are buying it. Technology is great. My managers are all technically competent and have decent people skills if not great. Very receptive to my problems and make sure I get to my solution.
cons: Don't know how great would be the chances to get promoted in my career.  Just a newbie here, and from what I have heard, it takes an average of 3-4 years to get promoted and get a pay-raise. Some of the business units are not doing that great, but atleast my BU is.

review_title: Fun but hard and long workdays/nights
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Richardson, TX
pros:
I work network consulting, not software dev, so we see much more support based and customer driven interactions.

 - Challenging Problem Sets 
 - New customer environments and topologies
 - New hardware and software deployments
 - Opportunities to develop both soft and hard skills
 - Opportunities to work with top-of-the-line hardware
 - Rarely have to work weekends

Been lucky with my managers at Cisco for the last 5 years - the two I have had are excellent.
cons:
- Long Long hours - Sometimes two or three days of all-nighters for maintenance windows
- Lots of red-tape - Everything has a system or a form 
- Lots of corporate directives - but no real explanation of the larger picture - I'm not sure what the direction of the company is.

review_title: Poor company only interested in short term gains at the expense of emplyees.
job_title: Product Manager in Lawrenceville, GA
pros: 4 weeks of vacation, remote working for some individuals.
cons: Dog eat dog company. If you are not living in San Jose, you will never get anywhere. They are good at spreading the propoganda stating they are such a good company, and love their employees so much, but reality is your just a lackey of your superiors. Huge egos within the company must be constantly fed, regardless of who is harmed by thier ambition. Increases in company revenue is driven by constant aquisitions, not organic growth, which is one reason why the stock is way off, and the company fell out of favor on Wall Street. If you are not willing to advance at all costs, this place is not for you.

review_title: A place you can live your life and enjoy having a family and yet still make a living working.
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: I like the fact I can work from home. I like that Cisco wants us to have a family life and not just a working life.
cons: If your a contractor you are stuck! there's no growth opportunities even though they claim there is.They lose out on a lot of talented internal workers because the company is so big and rather than empowering a contractor that is already here they look for externally talent.

review_title: Engineering Manager
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Bangalore
pros:
Cisco is a culture rich company, It spends huge effort in listening to its employees . It is one of the best company one can work for. If some one wants to learn and grow this is the place. Cisco's culture becomes part of your DNA year on year . 

Leadership is very inspiring, Previous CEO was the leader of the market . In-Comming CEO is dynamic. We need to see how he is going to take cisco to next level. 

Bangalore campus is awesome place to work . Employees are provided with world class infrastructure . Cab's are provided for every nook and corner of Banagalore, which are of great comfort. 
Great Work 
Great Work Life Balance 
Great Culture 
Awesome Vision
cons: Few Managers dont understand the culture , they spoil the name . But not many .

review_title: decent employer with lots of issues
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Jose, CA
pros: decent salary, good brand name, great on resume.
cons: ucs group has tight schedule and high turnover rate, those who stay long at the group as a result suffers and overworks. the manager has no concept of advising and promoting employess that is long forgotten. management will listen but whatever told em will come-in in one ear and comes-out the other ear. Each project comes with a unbelievably tight deadline and either project slip is common or deliver with questionable quality. Too many ignorant, dont care engineers with great job title but lost a common sense. Some engineers can not even configure basic networking and incapable of communicating in simple english language. As a result of all these mishap, technical clarity, know-how suffered and confusion, bias and complacency prevailed.

review_title: The initial excitement faded pretty soon
job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Vienna
pros: very flexible on work time, good compensation for on-Call, nice office
cons: micro management, too much management involvement & dictation in technical decisions and daily work, not properly included into Cisco (always felt like an forgotten outpost), resilient against industry standard technologies & methods & systems, patching stupid & fundamentally broken systems instead of replacing them with proper ones, too much on-call, local management had no say or information on what upper management is doing or deciding, Cisco treating people and contractors really bad when the earnings call is around the corner, not using external services and providers but trying to build in-house and fail hard, being a miserable open source citizen, not giving resources for proper testing & automation

review_title: Salesperson in CSAP program
job_title: Account Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Cisco Systems has an incredibly open employee culture from the top down, meaning that senior people within the company are always open to speaking and providing mentor-ship with early in career individuals. The overall culture and benefits of the company are great.  Autonomy and flexibility with working hours, opportunities for growth, great compensation, continually learning & wonderful coworkers and middle management.
cons: As a female who is early in my career, there is still the prevalence of a "boys club" and find that young males tend to find mentors in senior management/ leadership more easily then women.

review_title: Cisco is Great!!
job_title: Software Engineer-IV in Boxborough, MA
pros: Challenging work, always busy, new AI and cloud technology, competitive pay, gym on-site, management puts pressure on but not too much, work-life balance is great.
cons: Pay increases are only once every 3 or more years, depending on how you are perceived and your current grade level. However pay seems competitive (comparing GlassDoor numbers).  To get promoted you have to schmooze AND be really good at what you do, being good not enough. Always a lingering concern whether your BU may be hit by the next round of layoffs.

review_title: Cisco Global Virtual Sales Environment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Cisco is full of smart, driven, passionate, and helpful people. Despite the large size of the company, there's a true team feel. I've never worked anywhere else that encourages movement across the company like Cisco does. You're never siloed into a specific path which opens the doors for relocation or complete transition from one facet of the business to another. The on site amentiites such as the full service gym, doctor, etc. are second to none.
cons: Anyone would be lying if they said they didn't sometimes feel like their contribution was difficult to measure. However, with an operation as large as Cisco, you'll never win alone and you'll never lose alone. It's exciting to work for a best in breed organization. In the Global Virtual Sales Organization, the only true downfall is the strict no work from home policy. Even one day every two weeks would go the extra mile.

review_title: Becoming a typical corporate American business
job_title: Business Development Manager in London, England
pros: Great benefits, the majority of people are good to work with, you work with most of the big businesses in the UK and Internationally.
cons:
Can feel very remote, the UK is becoming a 'jobs for the boys' club. Change is always in the air. The UK sales management are bringing a political culture to Cisco that it didn't have before. They think they are a great deal better than they are.  Still a hardware business at heart and only pay lip service to becoming a services business. 
The portfolio is average, but works together quite well. Services are overpriced, with overstretch resources because many of the good ones are leaving.

review_title: Cisco is an outstanding place to live your dream career
job_title: Senior Director Shared Services in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Cisco is growing! There are a wide range of career opportunities for motivated workers.  They encourage employees to continuously learn and add to their skills. They recognize achievements fairly and promote based on accomplishments.  It is a fast paced environment where team work is cherished. There are no boundaries and innovation is sacred.  Your input will be valued if it is valuable. You can live your dreams at Cisco
cons: It is a very large company. Rather than consentrating on being a superstar you must concentrate on being an outstanding team member. You are measured on the value you bring to the project, team, organization and most importantly the customer. This may be more difficult for people who tend to do better solo.

review_title: Great place to work!
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: great work life balance.  Opportunities withing Cisco always come up.  Corporate communication from upper management is frequent and clear.  Compensation is reasonable and benefits are very good.  I worked at a number of other companies, startups and large companies alike.  Cisco treats their employees very good comparatively and expects good work out of them.  Overall the best managed company I've ever worked for in my 12 year career.  I worked at Cisco in the past, left and came back for this exact reason.  I recommend anyone to come and work for Cisco.  It is truly the best place to work.
cons: Live work and play anywhere, but working from home is discouraged.  I can see the reasoning behind this, but productivity must be measurable and as long as goals are met, working from home should be the norm to save commute time, fuel costs, environmental impact.

review_title: great place, lots of work to be done
job_title: Hardware Test Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: large company, lots of different oppertunities.  you can go into cisco as a nobody and leave as a professional networking guy with 5 cisco certs under your belt.  you have to take advantage of the situation.
cons: in the group i worked in, no work life balance, all work.  ive heard thats not normal for cisco though.  with the group i was in it wasnt the persuit of knowledge, it was the pursuit of getting it done. i would try to understand more about how things worked but would often get back the response from someone of "i dont know, why do you care"

review_title: Cisco: The hoards of Ghengis Khan
job_title: Senior Manager Business Development in San Jose, CA
pros: learn computer networking, meet smart people
cons: employees of small companies they purchase are promoted over existing staff, travel, layoffs and cutbacks with 40 Billion in the bank ??? The Chinese companies, HP, Juniper, IBM, and companies headed by displaced former employees are poised to eat their lunch

review_title: Good and safe job security, but slow salary/promotion
job_title: Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Lots of varied work environments, if you can pick the right one and adapt
Great, smart people, fun to work with
Working from home is widespread and gives you great work-life balance and flexible hours
cons:
People work all hours and weekends
Salary growth is slow after working for many years, options are not what they were in the past
People managers are far and few...most concentrate on delivery only and burning out their employees
People are rewarded more on saving a failing project with diving catches, rather than running a project smoothly with no surprises

review_title: Stability, but difficult to get salary increase
job_title: Finance Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco offers lots of training and is relatively stable and growing company to work for.  If you have great people and networking skills you will advance faster than average.
cons: Very difficult to get a raise or promotion.  If you get paid the market rate for your position after your 1st or 2nd year it will be difficult to get a raise without a promotion.  Cisco only offer salary increases if you are consider below market rate on Cisco's scale.

review_title: Fast moving company with lots of opportunities to learn new skills and move into faster growing areas.
job_title: Industry Consultant in San Jose, CA
pros:
1.  Competitive salaries and benefits.
2.  Lots of elearning opportunities, and you can study any area you want.
3.  Very open and communicative corporate culture--you can always find out about other business units and their strategies.
4.  Collaborative, team-based environment
5.  Great internal IT resources and support, including latest videoconferencing and webinar tools
cons:
1.  Lots of pressure to keep up with latest trends--you can't coast at Cisco.
2.  There are still internal power struggles and individuals can still wreak havoc with their teams and employees.
3.  Long hours
4.  Poor internal HR support
5.  Almost no admin support--you have to learn to do everything yourself

review_title: Interesting Times.....
job_title: Systems Engineer Manager in Richardson, TX
pros: Overall, great people.  Most are willing to chip in and help out across teams.  Competitive pay though it is slipping.  Still have several solid products.  One of the best sales channels in the industry.
cons: Lots of uncertainty as the company refocuses in FY11.  I expect to see several long time team members choose to leave the company during the next few months.  Expense budgets continue to shrink but expectations of employees are increasing.  Do more with less.  Headcount constraints are serious issue as back-fills are not being approved.  Competitive hires are difficult to acquire due to compensation falling behind the industry average.

review_title: Just and average experience so far...
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco Systems at its San Jose location offers a good work life balance. There are lots of perks including on-site health center, gym, and car wash. Work hours are pretty flexible, and can be managed easily, if you have a decent manager.
cons: Worst thing about working at Cisco is the limited job growth the company offers. Managers believe in building empires and maintaining strict hierarchy. Quite a large percentage of employees are at mid to senior level and most see Cisco as an employer where they can relax and draw a decent salary without being much innovative or working hard. Still somehow the stress level is too high.

review_title: Cisco is a great company , when you work in different company you will really see the difference
job_title: Customer Support Engineer in Amman
pros:
- equal opportunity 
-very solid training
cons: very busy work which will give you the chance to improve your skills in term of being multitask

review_title: Great Technology, Terrible Middle Management
job_title: Systems Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Offers great opportunity to to work with the best technology in the industry. Great flex time options working from home. Many opportunities to learn new technologies and free to move between internal jobs after one year in current job.
cons: Very bloated middle management, too many sales organizational restructuring severely affecting customer relationships. Middle management is very political, indifferent and not open to suggestions. If you want to keep your job then don't question management initiatives. Management will destroy your career if you are assertive and ambitious. The Cisco culture is long gone and has become a very difficult place to work with all the politics occurring. If you are not part of the good old boys club, then work will be frustrating and challenging.

review_title: Short term pain, long term gain
job_title: Technical Leader in Pune
pros: Cisco has diversified business. Recent acquisitions and future growth shows that the internet is going to explode in next 10 years and which will create very big opportunities for networking companies. Though the short-term prospects look weak/neutral, long-term prospects are huge depending on how we capitalize on the right opportunities.
cons: Due to recent layoffs (due to bad market conditions), overall moral is down. Some senior technical people are moving out - which is kind of hampering the future growth. As we lose lot of talent due to attrition, we may not be able to capitalize on the right opportunities in the future.

review_title: Struggling to make it through a long-term transition
job_title: Senior Operations Manager in London, England
pros: Some excellent people, particularly in the regional organisations and outside of corporate.  People work very hard in general and there is a remarkable level of commitment given the churn that the company has experienced in the last few years.  The company pays pretty well, and the ability to work from home, and be flexible in working hours is a huge plus.
cons: Corporate is still far too inward looking, political and self-obsessed.  Cisco aspires to be the #1 IT company in the world, but it struggles against younger, more nimble and more enlightened challengers in most of the markets in which it plays.

review_title: Software Engineer II
job_title: Software Engineer II in Bangalore
pros:
Flexible work hours
Process driven
Employee oriented policies
Work anywhere in the campus
Obviously, this is applicable for employees working as Cessna.
cons:
Slide in the personal growth - Easy to climb two or three steps up the ladder, but after that it is all downhill. One constantly needs to indulge in stuff other than work to go up the ladder faster than others.
Less hike - If not for promotion, the yearly hike is pretty less.
The management does not listen to the employee qualms and queries. Often I kept hearing that only when you put your papers down, they will listen to you
And these things are also not for employees working in Cessna, this is part and parcel of people working at RMZ Ecospace

review_title: Sweet 16!
job_title: Business Operations Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: I have worked at Cisco for 16 years. I have been fortunate to have been paired with the best managers, so I write this understanding that I've been blessed with a little pixie dust when it comes to the manager lottery. I get to work with very smart people and the occasional crazy person. I work from home and have tremendous flexibility. Cisco really cares about giving back, which I highly value. I have also been able to develop my career and get the support through training, coaching and mentoring.
cons: Cisco has some work to do on diversity but I am seeing a change through the new People Deal which makes me hopeful. I believe in Chuck and Fran, they have the right plan in place.

review_title: Great benefits, restructure frequently
job_title: Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Excellent benefits, newly introduced 13 weeks of maternity leave,  flexible work hours, allow occasional telecommuting. Board spectrum of internal positions available for career advancement. Many great managers who care about you as a person and as a professional, although there are also bad ones. Some groups are financially doing better than the others so sentiments across the board vary a lot.  Most employees are terrific. 
Many office spaces are remodeled recently and  snacks/coffee/fruits are provided as perks.
cons: There is constant restructuring of the company due to technology focus shift. Instability caused star/good employees to leave and laying off the existing ones, whether or not performance related, resulted in constantly low morale. It's a vicious cycle. Many are staying because they have family and they need the benefits.

review_title: Freedom is a massive benefit but isolation and uncertainty may set you back
job_title: Marketing Manager in London, England
pros: You'll never have freedom like you'll have at Cisco due to the flexible working hours and remote working culture. Generally, the company perks are great and salaries tend to be good
cons: Problem with the remote working policies is that your team mates will seldom come to the office and you may soon feel isolated. This also generates a bit of an issue with team spirit and collaboration. There are also multiple overlapping roles, and your role is likely to change or be cut on a yearly basis. Overall, this environment can become toxic and demotivating. It is also hard to be promoted unless you move jobs willingfully.

review_title: Stay away - unless you are Indian - Ethnic nepotism at large
job_title: Senior Technical Leader in San Jose, CA
pros:
Depends on the group you work for, there is an opportunity to acquire more skills
Descent pay
cons:
It is all about Indian nepotism. No chance to advance your career unless you ar indian.
Senior management are fake about what they call "diversity" which means for them to hire dependent and underpaid H1B workers so they could make millions every year.
Severe bias and discrimination across all levels

review_title: Good place to learn and leave
job_title: Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
1. Flexibility is given to employee to work and complete projects in time.
2. market leader in networking with great innovation and technologies to learn and work. 
3. High-Profile customers but you need to be technically solid to handle one.
4. add-on wold class campus
cons:
1. Low salaries compared to rest of networking companies. HR are mostly sleeping here as no actions to correct as per Market standard. Sometime Hike can take 3-4 years to happen. Because of these  good people leave.
2.Lot of work even  on weekends so WorkLifeBalance is a myth in Some BU's.
3.Lot of reorg. You might be working under one Manager one-day and might be working under other  after few days. Become difficult to settle at one team.

review_title: Decrease in salary - never heard of it in the industry.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Irvine, CA
pros: Benefits are good, especially generous PTO. 401K matching is decent.
cons: Base pay got reduced by around 6% in one year.  I never heard of this situation in the industry.  New comp plan for systems engineers is not geared to pay well.  Due to macro and micro economic reasons, if goal attainment is less than 100%, take home pay will be lower in the new comp plan.  Leadership team boasts about the upside, but does not provide any reasoning for reducing the base.

review_title: Now a Median Company to Work for
job_title: Software Engineer-III in San Jose, CA
pros:
Good company to work with after a couple of years of your start of career. 
Will have more development opportunities depending on your team and the work they contribute for the company.  Has good work-life balance, it's flexible in this aspect. 
Good health insurance options and 401K match.
cons:
No clarity on bonus and promotions, will take few years  for them and minimal hike in salary. 
Managers have absolute control of your career, HR is non-existent.
Compensation is still below industry standards. 
Lots of Politics inside the teams, frustrating for employees as they don't get chance to work on where their interest lies.
Lay-offs keep happening twice a year.

review_title: Cisco -- many positives, but also some negatives
job_title: Software Engineer III in San Jose, CA
pros:
* Great name recognition on your resume
* Typically smart and competent coworkers
* Wide market deployment for Cisco hardware, good exposure to customers
* Stable company
* Attention to good development practices like code review, unit test, etc.
* Good benefits
cons:
* Big company means a lot of momentum, so change happens slowly
* Support and maintenance for existing/legacy software can be frustrating
* Some managers have no personal lives and expect you to behave similarly, often with the expectation of constant availability by email and working on weekends
* Too much process slows down the pace of development

review_title: Great company that grew too fast
job_title: Senior Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: People here are very smart and want to be innovative.  TelePresence is a great product and the Smart+Connected Communities works is interesting.  There are a lot of opportunities to work with other groups on projects.  Cisco's reputation is still very strong, which helps when you want to work with others outside the company.
cons: Management is lost - this recent restructuring is a last minute reaction to things many people below Director level could see coming. There's too much redundancy and the company needs better management systems and IT tools.  The pay is good for the industry, but raises are non-existent and stock awards are kind of worthless considering the current share price.

review_title: Disenchanted and disempowered at Cisco Systems
job_title: Network Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: They have a relaxed remote work policy, which does make it much easier to work from home. They do give time off when needed, no questions asked, but this seems to be getting more attention lately as they are squeezing belts more.
cons: The morale there sucks! They are squeezing people's ability to work as they used to. They have reorganized into a silo'd organization that does not allow any freedoms to work without the beaureaucratic bs. The way they do reviews is certainly not fair especially when it is tied to your bonuses. They compare you to each other and not how you have performed against your annual goals. This way they can get more work out of you and pay you less. And it is getting worse! Did I mention the morale there sucks!

review_title: Treats employees with respect but no longer compensates them for hard work
job_title: Software Engineer III in Richardson, TX
pros: Great people and working environment, Integrity and Honesty, Treats employees well in tough times such as family emergencies or layoffs.  Good mobility within the company.
cons: Many of the benefits they used to provide to attract and retain employees are gone.  Starting salaries are good but don't count on getting a raise.  Once upon a time everything you needed was on the internal company website and easy to get to.  Now the information is outdated and the new stuff is hard to find.  There is no more human in the human resources department.

review_title: The once great company that has lost its vision.
job_title: Technical Leader in Boxborough, MA
pros: Cisco produces great products. This was really the manifestation of a world-class engineering team. It also offers good work-life balance.
cons: Unfortunately upper management proved that they had lost their vision. Time and again they have gone into senseless reorganizations that created lots of churn but little tangible results. It was in an eternal confusion between growth and value. Countless resources were squandered into new adventures, which either didn't generate the kind of revenue to lift the company's "growth", or became obsolete before realization because of newer trendier fab. Overall, Cisco was no longer the market leader but has rather become the follower. Given its size, chasing after new "fab" isn't exactly the best exercise. Eventually the core business will bleed so much that it won't be able to sustain the "innovations".

review_title: Not in Kansas any more
job_title: Project Manager in Boxborough, MA
pros: Great caliber of people to work with.  The best and brightest in all areas.  Fast paced, great comp and benefits
cons: Recent years have seen a shift in corporate culture.  Thought Cisco has always been focused on profit and growth it was always done with the employees in mind.  Recent pressures of the stock holders and the IT market have seen a shift to more main stream corporate operating cultures.  Lay-offs are more common in Cisco now and there is less alignment between what the CEO "says" is the focus and what is actually executed.  The word "family" has a diminished meaning in the Cisco culture.  Less reward for performance at the discretion of line managers.

review_title: Low Energy and Weak Leadership
job_title: Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Market leadership in most areas which is a good place to be as a marketer.  Despite weaknesses, many of Cisco's customer's have no real options other than Cisco.  High salaries/bonuses and good productivity tools.
cons: Leadership that's indecisive and often inept - certainly in Marketing. Chamber's departure was probably due but they've slipped since then. Strategy that's seldom articulately communicated.  Put's on a good face that they care about employees but it's a very low energy, poor people management environment.  They have a thing they call "the people deal."  Never really understood what that meant but the inside joke is that it means yearly layoffs, which is not a joke. No stock appreciation.

review_title: Reorg is a dirty word...
job_title: IT Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Great company to work for, especially with constant focus on cutting-edge technologies and diversification into new areas of IT infrastructure and applications. Benefits are excellent.
cons: Constant reorgs over the past few years means slim chances of moving into a position that is a better fit for the employee. Getting your "foot in the door" may not necessarily be the best way to advance your career, whether an employee or contractor. I have seen good managers with 10-15+ years get laid off during these reorgs, so no one is safe.

review_title: Cisco SP Routing Unit Review
job_title: Tech Lead in Bangalore
pros: You get recognized as someone who has worked on Cisco IOS platforms.
cons:
I have been in Cisco for more than a decade and worked across multiple business units.
Cisco SP routing business unit (IOS-XR) is one of the bad experiences of my career.
The leadership is really spineless and visionless.
The managers here are merely task managers rather than people managers.
Someone needs to make them understand that they need to take care of people and people
will take care of work themselves.
Instead, they give frivolous arguments and metrics to run away from their responsibility to motivate
and retain good employees.

review_title: Love where I work
job_title: Marketing Director in San Jose, CA
pros:
Placeism - Cisco doesn't discriminate about where you are working, as long as you ARE working.  We are truly global - and it doesn't matter if you sit on campus, on your living room couch or on a plane - as long as you are engaged.  We have amazing collaboration tools, including Webex, that allows us to use video and be virtual/present anywhere.  

Our executives, especially at the top, are very accessible and engaging.  They are incredibly transparent.  Our CEO and his leaders host a monthly all-employee meeting through CiscoTV, and have a team of people answering questions about anything and everything.
cons:
We are a larger, more diverse company in terms of products, so you don't always see regular salary increases, and stock for the average worker is probably non-existent.
While we are hiring, it helps if you know someone, as things can get lost.

review_title: AMAZING benefits & culture, need better communication
job_title: Business Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
- Great benefits
- Inclusive, diverse, open-minded culture
- Employees are friendly
- 'Teams are families' mindset (fun activities with teams, sports days, lunches, etc)
- Many activities to get involved in (clubs, events, IM sports, employee groups, etc)
- On-campus health center and gym
- Well-stocked break & locker rooms
- Maternity & prayer rooms available
- Employee purchasing program with rewards
- Additional rewards through connected recognition
- Diverse Executive Leadership Team (and executive visibility)
- Opportunities for leadership, impact, and exposure
cons:
- Lack of inter-company/team communication due to possibly too many pathways (email, Jabber, text, Spark, etc)
- Not enough employees know how to not 'reply all'
- 'Open' workspaces are putting off some employees (less space to call their own)
- If you don't work directly with corporate, can be hard to get raises/promotions

review_title: Great leadership, amazing coworkers, excellent benefits
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Senior management team is knowledgeable, transparent, sincere, and has successfully seen the company through many transitions. Co-workers care about their work, help one another, and strive to achieve high quality and innovation. The benefits and flexibility are excellent and are a tangible way the company shows respect and care for the individual. I love Time2Give (1 week of time off so I can give back to the community), parent / grandparent time off when a child is born, global focus on reducing waste / carbon footprint (i.e. composting of food scraps at some sites), and on and on.
cons: It's a large company, there are some inefficiencies, some competition between business units, especially at the middle management level.

review_title: Cisco, one great company to work for.
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Opportunities everywhere, you are given a job to do and most of the time you have a great deal of flexibility on how you can execute it. Cisco is like many small companies that you can access and move into, gaining experience, knowledge, and depth in your career path. All that and I can telecommute, what's there not to like?
cons: Some people have a hard time with the passionate and aggressive way that Cisco goes about its business. You need to 'get it' and get on with it fast. No one wants to hear you whining about how hard it is to do what you need to do. Ask for advice, research your problem, propose and solution and make a decision. Unfortunately some of those who don't get are still around.

review_title: Chambers should pay attention not only to the bottom line of the company, but to the bottom people and up a couple level
job_title: Software Engineer III in San Jose, CA
pros:
Name recognition. Leader in industry.
My managers were cordial, but I often felt alienated compared to my Indian peers. It was discouraging feeling.
cons:
Not diverse. If you're not from India and Middle East, you excluded from promotions and favoritism.
Managers are not properly trained. If you're technically strong and want to be a manager, you will be one. That should not be the only prerequisite to lead a team. Proper management training is a must.

review_title: Hi Tech Call Center
job_title: Customer Support Engineer in Richardson, TX
pros:
Very decent salary. Mine was at 97% of the market. 
Excellent base to become technical but don't stay too long in TAC. 
Excellent benefits package.
Exciting if you like to work on web sessions with customers. If you are successfully, then it really shows to future employers that you have awesome communication skills
cons:
4 weeks of vacation is amazing but with sick days as part of it, it is horrible. 
No promotions whatsoever. Only if you are phenomenally technical and are a good talker
Bonuses not distributed fairly.
Constant stress of being rated by customer satisfaction surveys. Bad customer sat scores can get you fired.
No cost of living raise.
Just like most places, politics and bureaucracy. A whole lost of senior management does not even have a bachelors.

review_title: great all-around job
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Sydney
pros: most people are pretty cool.  internal CEO birthday chats (although i was never allowed to go somehow when i worked in SJ). global footprint - lots of places to work remotely. awesome remote access policy and flexible work highly encouraged.  very cool labs and engineering resources.  some really great people developing and doing really great things.  global opportunities and good emphasis on career growth.
cons: lots of middle layers to the company. oodles of inane processes. bad mix of folks who care versus folks who don't. sharply waning amount of time or budget for training (especially in customer support).  some places where awful line managers can hide and fester.  not everyone buys into "one cisco".  many misplaced intentions and forced initiatives.

review_title: Good company but terrible management
job_title: Programs Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: Fair salary and compensation. Nice to have option to work from home.
cons: Some of the most  arrogant and ill trained managers in the industry. The idea of managers at Cisco is if you are a skilled NCE, you are a good manager. Managers are empowered to do everything right or wrong and they have the practice of hiring very young managers who may have excelled in the field. The management style is like in the army, generals talk to generals and no one cares or listens otherwise. Emails never get responded and no one listens to voicemail. One of the most arrogant companies to work for and it takes months or years to implement a program

review_title: Not what you think it is
job_title: Software Developer in San Jose, CA
pros: People are friendly. Broad range of products to pick and choose from to build out experience in computing.
cons: So much politics and in fighting. Departments hate each other to an extreme. You can not move or transfer to another department because managers are rated against how many FTE (full time employees) they have. Nobody wants to give up a head count or risk getting laid off next. The C-levels are only considered about shareholders not employees. For example; nearly 70% of the corp workforce is contractor based so guess who also writes your evaluations…yep… Nobody has got a rise in 3 years. Although they did give the Dear Leader Chambers 20+ million dollar raise and did I mention it was the same day he lauded off 4500 people? Do like the rest of silicon valley, work there for a couple years, then move on.

review_title: Change at Cisco
job_title: Account Manager in London, England
pros: Great culture, fantastic people, diverse opportunity across geo and segment, brand, global opportunity and strength of balance sheet, innovation and transformation.  Benefits good, flexible working excellent, real efforts to change and grow people.
cons: Promotion still outdated and based on who you know - management give advice to move and rotate within the business yet promote people who stay put.  Attempts to increase female senior management % still feels slow and limited, focus primarily on young women entering IT or women with children.  Missing the 'mid layer' and losing talent accordingly.  Too much focus on what it costs to promote people (i.e. grade increase) than promoting the right person

review_title: Likely a good place for the start of your career for a few years.  For older, US workers plan on a short stay
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
• Depending on position potentially good pay
• Some potentially interesting projects in security, IoT
• Strong existing customer relationships and cashflow
cons:
• Too much internal politics - Cisco's main competition seems to be itself
• Appears unable to innovate and will need to continue to acquire technologies and then continue annual limited restructuring (layoffs) to keep workforce expense in check 
• Lack of diversity in the work force
• In the midst of massive organizational turnover at all levels

review_title: Best in its class
job_title: Software Developer in Pune
pros:
1. Proper Work-life balance, flexible hours, work-from-home option. 
2. Recently, good work is flowing in. 
3. Very smart colleagues, very respectful and helping too.
4. Good culture and company values.
5. Good recreational facilities (Quiet rooms, gym, TT and foosball tables, carrom, Massage chairs, Nap rooms, etc.)
cons:
1. Slow growth professionally, too much hierarchy. 
2. Removed bi-yearly appraisal, now its yearly. 
Only related to a particular Business Unit in which I work,
Revenue going down (customers moving to cloud platform, so less income from costly hardware ), and so
3. Less hike/promotions. 
4. Frequent layoffs, not dependent on performance.  
5. Very less food options in cafeteria. 
(Above 3 does not apply to other Business Units)

review_title: Good work life balance but poor growth
job_title: Software Engineer IV in Bangalore
pros: Great offices and infrastructure - cafeteria, club house, gym and sports facilities are excellent. Transport facility is very good. Cisco Campus is truly wonderful to work in. Flexible work hours and still friendly to work from home ( though this has decreased over the years).  Lot of learning programs and trainings. Freshers may like the in-house box office, massage chairs and video games arcade.
cons: Snail pace of career progression, learnings are minimal unless you take it upon yourself to look into new areas and sign up for programs. Not much opportunity to travel. Frequent re-orgs. In last 3-4 years, no hikes, low or deferred bonuses and no RSUs. Slow to embrace change.

review_title: Technical Leader in Cisco Service Provider, India
job_title: Technical Leader in Bangalore
pros:
Opportunity to work on latest technologies and evolving IOS-XR 
which is widely acknowledged for its high quality.
Excellent, innovative and challenging road map across various product lines in Access / Edge / Core Networks.
Working with top talents in the Industry across geographies.
Interaction with Cross functional teams like Product Marketing, Customer Account teams and Sales TMEs .
Encouragement to change the roles based on the strengths and skill sets.
World Class work environment which is collaboration oriented and supported by  well maintained  infrastructure. 
One of the best and secure Employee Transport facilities.
cons:
Inability to change the culture across all the team members to overcome hurdles.
Too many context switches are demanding and they turn out to be counter productive.
Slow career growth due to large teams.

review_title: Could be more professional
job_title: Consulting Engineer in Kraków
pros: Good training options if you can get. Possibilities of working among different technologies even the cutting edge ones, good opportunities and resources to become CCIE.
cons: Huge salary discrimination between sites. Salaries are not increased accordingly as the grade increases. Management plays on your personal stuff not to promote you. Some managers don’t care about promotion of non-local people, they care about local ones. Sometimes management does mobbing to break your morale to make you ready to execute any type of work within the team out of the career plan of yourself.

review_title: Incompetence Principle Engineer and executives
job_title: Senior Tech Lead in San Jose, CA
pros:
Balance life and work. Many folks I know only works for few hours a day because they don't have much work to do.
Good place for those who cannot code but can talk well.
Good place for those has good connection.
