A lot of loyal customers, even the products  are way worse than competitors. The loyal customers still buy it.
cons: Many senior managers are promoted to Principle Engineer because the pay is equivalent to director. However, many of them are not qualified and incompetence. They make a lot of stupid design decision. At one point, I feel sorry for the customers. Many executives cannot tell a good solid technical team vs a weak one. At the end, cut the strong team and let the lousy team to take care the project. No wonder, the company has to layoff and lose market share.

review_title: Great benefits, but continuous transformation is draining
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, telecommuting, cafeterias in larger campuses.
cons: The dark side of innovation and transformation is the continuous churn in organizations struggling to define themselves, and justify or and defend their relevancy.  Promoting leaders who think leadership is more about intellectual posturing  than delivering something of value, and not having the courage to make the really tough decisions, leaving teams languishing without support

review_title: Great place to develop yourself
job_title: Systems Engineer in Tokyo
pros:
- Always surrounded by excellent colleagues who motivate me to pursue the state-of-the-art technologies (which aren't restricted only in network)
- Workplace flexibility allows me to be well-balancing my work-and-life. Sometimes, I work very hard and feel tired, but on the other hands, I also have lots of time to develop myself by studying new areas of technologies and attending various external tech events. Cisco actively invests my development in any categories of technologies because any of them can be connected with Cisco's. As an engineer, this environment is very exciting and always feel fun to have been in the leading tech company.
cons:
- It depends on the customers, but when they are less motivated to learn new technologies and just focusing on financial side, I feel boring and it is less challenging because the deals can be closed only by sales person.
- Less salaries than account managers

review_title: Cisco - too large, too slow and trying hard to change from a box seller to a software company
job_title: Senior Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: It's a job, good health benefits
cons: Bureaucracy, management that speaks out of both sides of their mouth. Here are the rules, but they don't follow them. Website that is impossible to navigate.  No live people to talk to when you have issues.  "open a help ticket" Compensation is weak.  So tired of hearing that there is no money for raises and getting stock that is underwater instead.  Technology is wonderful, but people make it all happen.  Reward them!

review_title: What happens when a great company grows very large
job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros:
Strong senior management team with strategy and vision for market transformation
Strong leadership team with high ethics
Cultural diversity
Good place to start career and get experience
Good benefits and 401k
cons:
Employees using empowerment and freedom from management to abuse system
Lack of management visibility to activities of employees - employees abuse this
Good amount of tenured employees with connections that manipulate system
LIttle accountability on behalf of employees
Image going to work and listen to coworkers brag about taking +3 hour lunches

review_title: The Truman show
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Jose, CA
pros:
After all these cutbacks, benefits are still good
Flexibility to work from home (can be a double edged sword)
Access to latest tools
Peers are generally nice to each other
cons:
No realistic prospects for career advancement
Innovation cannot be mandated when we are expected to work at odd hours
Cost cutting has gone to ridiculous extremes with 'no print' days.
steady loss of benefits and perks from 2000
Management is good at power point programming and taking credit.
Can get laid off for being at the wrong place - has nothing to do with performance in most cases.
Reminded of the movie Truman show where everything is orchestrated, and you are supposed to be happy.

review_title: Solid, Steady Place to Work But Be Prepared to be One Guppy Among Many in a Large Lake
job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros:
* Senior management genuinely treats employees like family
* Tremendous commitment to giving back to the community
* Solid financial foundation and management with plenty of resources to invest
* Great telecommuniting and flexible schedule policy
* Strong culture of candid and open communications from management
cons:
* Increasingly bureaucratic
* Too San Jose-centric... All policies, meetings, and processes are catered to San Jose
* Jobs becoming increasingly more narrowly defined with little room for learning and growth into adjacent areas
* Promotions and movement are still largely dependent on whom you know

review_title: The largest networking / infrastructure company with end to end solutions for enterprise deployments
job_title: Customer Support Engineer in Milpitas, CA
pros:
* Lots of opportunity to find additional positions of interest within the company
* Stable workforce so long as you are not involved in a 'fringe' technology team being phased out
* Generous opportunity to find other positions if restructuring requires, and generous package in lieu of another position if you so choose
cons: * Slow to move into some newer technologies, though rapidly changing that attitude this past year

review_title: Pros and Cons at Cisco for an SE
job_title: Systems Engineer in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: Team work is a constant and you can always rely on your peers. Great to be able to work from home. As a Systems Engineer, there are many learning paths to choose from. You have to be a quick learner and being able to give the extra mile. Company always looks to get the best people. Not a silos oriented company. Very good compensation packages, vacations and days off.
cons: Long journeys that may include some weekends, this may compromise the work-life balance. Sometimes managers lack the skills to manage people and provide meaningful feedback. As in any large company, moving forward your career takes a lot of time.

review_title: Software Engineer IV and Technical Marketing engineers view
job_title: Software Engineer IV in Wilmington, MA
pros: There were a number of good aspects. They had good benefits and were well run from an HR perspective. There were also plenty of opportunities for horizontal moves but you just need to be located in the right countries or corner of the nation.
cons: The biggest negative I see here is that they are outsourcing the heck out of the place. From software development and support to HR and desktop support. I was getting to the opinion that the majority of the folks you speak with now are all contractors. I understand it's all about the stockholders equity but it's just not what it used to be.

review_title: Re-inventors required
job_title: Manager, Prod Marketing in San Jose, CA
pros:
Working at Cisco, especially now, is pretty fun.  It has been a fast-paced and contently changing environment for years but in just the last thirty months the tempo has increased. Everyone seems more focused and better aligned as the company. This is as the company transitions to a more "business outcomes" mindset - from selling "eyeglasses" to selling "better vision".  

But you must be able to re-invent yourself with some frequency and deal with change.

I do not think there has been a better time to be at Cisco than right now.
cons: Opportunities must be sought out.  Compensation seems to lag "valley" benchmarks for non-executive level employees. Work/life balance sometimes gets akimbo. Frugality sometimes hamstrings success.

review_title: Great Place to Intern
job_title: Supply Chain Operations Intern in San Jose, CA
pros: I was a summer intern in the supply chain and I had a fantastic time! Great coworkers who were always willing to help, fun perks, competitive salary, and a real-world look at what industry is like. The people I worked with really made me feel appreciated too, and that was a huge plus.
cons: While I got good experience and lots to talk about in interviews, I don't know how much my work actually helped the company. Near the end of my internship I got the feeling that the interns from the year before had done the exact same projects we were assigned to do, making it almost feel like our time was wasted. I wish our projects had more of an impact on the company.

review_title: One week in and loving it!
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Denver, CO
pros: People are passionate about the strategy the new CEO has laid out, including the opportunity to transform the culture to make sure Cisco continues to be a leading technology company. They may not have all the answers on how they will do it, but they are willing to try different approaches and there is a very open, transparent approach being taken to how things will be done in the future to accomplish lofty goals and an inspiring vision.
cons: Cisco is a large company and sometimes getting easy things done can be overly complex. They also need a better tool that enable teams to collaborate on editing files in real-time to save time managing through file changes when working across large groups.

review_title: Account Manager
job_title: Account Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexibility, great benefits ( healthcare, travel,education and additional perks), positive work environment if you are within the right team. You will create relationships, friends and maybe even family. Respect, acknowledgment, equal rights. Its a great company to work for. Look for divisions like Channels and Meraki.
cons: Hard to move up or lateral. Lack of company vision and strategy towards the cloud, data center, and hardware commoditization. Services are too expensive. Sometimes they push AM's to sell solutions and the company eliminate the BU in less than a year causing sales teams and customers to suffer. The company is struggling to move fast, keep up with technology. I believe we lost our WHY and what we were good at... Tried to do too many things and can't deliver just to stay competitive on the market.

review_title: What is the strategy ?
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Bedfont, England
pros: Great people who want to make a difference. Very clever people and a true can-do attitude. This is a company which could have a great future but they need to focus on areas which have the best growth potential
cons: No clear business nor technology strategy. Cloud solutions are months away even though the mantra is Cloud, Cloud, Cloud. Current "limited restructuring" feels like it is more based around cutting costs rather than for for role, with no sense for technology strategy.  Morale is on a downward spiral.  This is a company which could have a great future but the company tend to focus on who has been best at telling people what a great job they do...

review_title: My concept of Cisco
job_title: Systems Engineer in Bogotá, Bogota
pros: The people that work in Cisco are great persons. Cisco encourages its employees to always be trained and up-to-date and offers free training to their employees.  Cisco is a financially stable company and offers peace of mind, and Cisco will also ensure that its employees grow professionally within the company. Employees are free to work from home whenever they want, there are no inconveniences to request permission to go out to solve personal issues, that is Cisco is very flexible.
cons: In Cisco sometimes there are many strategic changes at the organizational level and this causes employees not to be clear business objectives and it is also possible that by these changes one group of employees has a manager and another manager another month.

review_title: Great company, but not a good place to start
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Brussels
pros: Great benefits, nice culture and interesting projects.
cons: There is a lot of people, it's really hard to get a promotion, even when you do, it really doesn't change a thing, you keep doing the same everyday. It's different to be in Cisco Mexico, small offices, with little culture of integration, I assume is different if you are in RTP or San Jose. Work shifts varies and it is really hard to balance your personal life with your work. Managers won't trust you easily to get you new projects and experiences. You kind of get stuck in the same place forever.

review_title: Writing software that gets used. A lot.
job_title: Software Technical Lead in Ciudad de Mexico
pros:
Your software gets used by lots of people. They've got the marketting and sales machine so
if you write good software it will get used. I worked for a LOT of startups and Cisco's major competitors and developed good code which never succeeded in the market. (One bridge won prizes as the fastest in the world at the time, but that company only sold a few hundred, while Cisco sold hundreds of thousands of switches in their Catalyst line.) At the end of the day you really want your work to matter.
cons: IOS is supported on dozens of platforms so often bugs have to be ported to dozens or (for rare critical and pervasive bugs) even hundreds of software branches. While there are tools to help, you can feel like a drone when you have to work on maintenance.

review_title: I really enjoy being part of the "Cisco Family"
job_title: Systems Engineer in Boxborough, MA
pros: I can't say enough great things about working for Cisco.   The teamwork is outstanding; I've never seen a group of people pull together to get a job done like they do at Cisco.  People from all of the organizations are extremely helpful, and want to see you succeed.  The culture of the company is very laid back in that you have complete control over your schedule.  If you want to work from home, or from anywhere, that is totally acceptable.  The benefits and perks are also some of the best in the industry.
cons: Cisco is not a job, it's a lifestyle.  Almost everyone who works here is basically "on" 24/7, but you don't really mind because you enjoy what you're doing, and it's not taken for granted.

review_title: Was great, but is now going in the direction of Lucent and Nortel.
job_title: Software Engineer IV in Madrid
pros:
Benefits - PTO, Health, Dental, Vision insurance.
Gives you a solid grounding in Networking
Ample of learning opportunities
Work+Life Balance
Good, Smart Co-workers
cons:
Too much politics at each level. Products and projects get canned, not because they don't make strategic sense, but because of political alignments. Products get built, again, not because they make strategic sense, but because of political alignments.

People can get stuck in their positions for a long time. As some other reviewer said, promotions are based on who licks best.

Too much process. Also, too many new hires in terms of recent college grads. Over a half of them are not even worth hiring. If the BUs were given a choice to hire people, I am sure, more than half of them would be rejects.

review_title: It's kind of like the mob...
job_title: in London, England
pros: Overall, Cisco is a good company to its employees.   An open environment of communication, hard working, likeable people, they treat their employees well.
cons: Note how I said they treat their employees well...not their contractors.   It seems like once you 'get made' (like in the mob) going from contractor to employee...you're in the inner circle and get the respect, periodic salary increases and benefits that a company of this size can provide.  If you're a contractor...you're in a dead end position and will have to fight hard for any increases in your pay rate...and even then they can take it away, blaming it on the economy.

review_title: Great creative place in the beginning, lousy place to work now
job_title: Tech Lead in Brussels
pros: good coworker, some good technologies good engineers
cons:
Cisco now is place great for middle level manegement and up (director and up). These extreme ambitous managers move around different BUs, divisions, imprint their styles and leave for better opportunity to go up.  What these mean to rank and file is constant change for no good reason, very counter productive.
Cisco now is all about manage up, what your manager's preception of you is all that matter. Even if you suck but your manager like you, you will be fine. 
This manage up culture is a chain reason, stupid decision from the no clues extreme ambitous executives trump any grassroot common sense. That's why Cisco sucks so much in the last 2 years.
The remote work center seriously back fire, it is one of the most counter productive idea in Cisco.

review_title: This, too, shall pass
job_title: in Chicago, IL
pros: It's a given that you'll meet some very smart people at a company like Cisco. What surprises and delights you is meeting and then getting to work closely with the very funny ones who somehow slipped through HR vetting. They bring soul and character and fun to what could otherwise be the beige-est place on earth. They are the basis for all camaraderie at Cisco.
cons: Unrealistic project schedules are alive and well at Cisco. So are fiefdoms and power grabs. So is a congenital inability to staff projects appropriately.

review_title: Bittersweet
job_title: Operations Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexible work schedule. Still some terrific folks around, despite the politicians' best efforts to eradicate the few free-thinkers left.
cons: Those of us who have been around longer than 10 years remember Cisco as a cutting-edge environment. Agile and young, we used to make smart, strategic decisions. Smart acquisitions. It used to be fun. We're going on nearly a decade of indecisive leadership, unreasonable changes, lack of strategy, and all our decisions seem to be based on politics. It feels as though we've lost our competitive edge in the market and employees across the company are feeling its de-motivating effects. Pulse scores are low, opportunity is low, morale is low.

review_title: Cisco treats employees well but really has no idea where they are headed
job_title: ASIC Design Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Allow you to select Macs as your computer to use.  Good bonuses and salary.  Competitive benefits. Nice facilities to work in.
cons: Upper management is destroying the company by having no clue to where they are going or what business they are in.  Cisco's future is unfortunately to become like HP where engineering is nearly absent and the products are very sub-par.

review_title: A $2.3b quarterly profit and 4,000 layoffs...
job_title: Director in San Jose, CA
pros: A strong strategic view of the markets and the company's ability to find the right products that customers need keep Cisco at the forefront of their industry. Well-paying bonuses.
cons: Despite what executive management says, it really is more about shareholders than employees.  It's officially a pattern/trend when layoffs happen every year, it isn't just an adjustment.  Investment in employees isn't the company philosophy when base pay raises haven't been broadly given in many years.

review_title: A former GREAT company that's subsequently lost it's way....
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: A large diversified company with plenty of opportunities to move around. Good compensation and benefits. Work-life balance can be great or terrible depending on your organization.
cons: A culture of empowerment, collaboration and shared success, which had always been one of Cisco's greatest success factors, is weak, if not non-existent today. Constant layoffs and a painful transformation has created a very defensive, divisive and competitive culture. The company's top talent appear to be leaving at an alarming rate. Executive/senior leadership team appears to value cronyism and obfuscation rather than hard work, execution and accountability.

review_title: Cisco - Innovation and Decision Making is key to longevity
job_title: Program Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Have Internet Access? Work anywhere.
Cisco has a great set of core values
The working environment is positive.  Cisco employees are professional and results oriented. 
There is a healthy amount of rewards and recognition
Cisco takes corporate social responsibility seriously. I enjoy having time to volunteer and giving back to the community representing  Cisco
cons:
Annual Layoffs - Cisco is bleeding top talent and top talent would think twice about joining this company.  Needs to get smarter around hiring practices as to limit the annual layoff trend.
Change Fatigue - It is really unclear if the Cisco Strategies work because Cisco is in a constant rate of change.
Executive Leadership is very shy about making decisions or there is too much collaboration and not enough directive decision making.

review_title: Hit or Miss
job_title: Engineer TAC & HTTS in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Cisco has the resources to do anything they want.  If they want to fix a problem they can.  The saying at Cisco is, there are jobs.. just not a lot of good ones.
cons: The last 20 years created a huge outsourcing black hole, and along with that many engineers were brought into the US to support customers here and abroad.  Unfortunately they don't speak English very well, and many are completely unintelligible.  Some of the managers are also from India and don't want to remove these folks, and so the work gets piled onto the US engineers to make up for them.. so you'll become their mule.

review_title: IT Project Manager
job_title: IT Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Autonomy and ability to work from home with the permission of your supervisor. Open floor plan and friendly co-workers. Opportunity of internal application for full-time jobs.
cons: Little to no on-boarding process, expected to hit the ground running with little to no guidance unless you ask questions and are persistent about learning the landscape. Contractors are not able to attend many meetings even if it is for your direct managers and his (full-time) reports. Hear a lot of gossip through the grapevine which actually impacts your projects.

review_title: Cisco is a great workplace for women
job_title: Senior Director in San Jose, CA
pros:
Cisco is a great workplace for women. I feel that I have management support all the way to the top and great colleagues.  

We have regular events to mentor, develop and inspire women.  I work with partners, so I know that is not always the case in the Silicon Valley, especially in engineering.  

Also I have great role models to look up to.  In which other large tech company half of CEO reports are women, and not just in traditionally female functions like marketing? I can't think of any other.
cons: I do feel that Cisco can do better in the compensation area. Until recently I was paid less than my male colleagues even though I performed better. My current manager worked to bring me up the curve from where my first manager placed me, but it took a while.

review_title: Finance at Cisco Systems Is A Great Place to Work!
job_title: Compliance Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Job Rotation is the only reason why I've been here for 18 years! Once you master your role--usually in 3-4 years, then you can rotate to a new role where you can take on more responsibility and learn new skills. This has allowed me to take new roles without changing companies and I've been able to carry over things like equity, PTO, etc.
cons: In the past I've taken some parallel positions just to learn something new. It may be that If I had stayed in  a role for a longer tenure then maybe I would have been promoted faster--but who knows.

review_title: Cisco - where the BEST come to work.
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: If you're interested in continuous learning, Cisco is the place for you.  You also get to work with the best and brightest in the industry.  Knowledge and information sharing is prevalent, and you feel like you're making a difference with the customer.  Everyone is willing to help out, communication is easy and free-flowing.
cons: It is extremely difficult to get ahead.  Everyone works hard and is very intelligent.  This means that if you were a big fish in a small pond before, you'll be average at Cisco.  This may or may not be a blow to your ego, but I find it is hard to be recognized as an expert - since everyone is an expert.  The trick is to specialize and become the go-to person for a particular technology.

review_title: Need to have friends in the right places
job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros: Great benefits,  Great flexibility in how and where you work.  Financially well run.  Sales team the best in the business.
cons: Unless you have someone senior to sponsor your career you are not going anywhere.     The culture is totally passive aggressive.  Everyone is extremely pleasant in meetings but the sabotaging and drama behind the scenes would make any reality show green with envy.  The plot lines here would fill many seasons of the “The Office”.  If you have a good sense of humor is quite hilarious to watch from the sidelines.

review_title: Cisco had now devolved to resemble HP
job_title: Senior Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Lots of smart people. Great technologies. Fair Policies. Reasonable pay.
cons:
There are so many operating committees that senior management really does not know how to get a decision out of them. I worked at Cisco for over 12 years. In my early career there I could not wait to get to work. You actually could make a difference in the way we did business. No Longer!
Cisco imported so many managers from HP that Cisco now has HP's culture. There is still a high level of activity for the employee's only now most of it is meaningless busy work. Get

review_title: Loved the people, the politics? - not so much!
job_title: Strategic Planning in San Jose, CA
pros: Lots of smart people. The overall quality of talent is excellent, and there is a strong vibe of a demand for excellence.  The company is willing to change tacks, and quite quickly, which is important in today's world, and impressive for a company of its size.
cons:
As much time is spent on staking out and maintaining one's "territory" as on actually working. Most inquiries to other dept's for assistance/co-operation are treated as threats and much effort is put into attempting to eviscerate or eliminate those that seem to provide a threat to one's territory.  Creates a pretty unproductive working environment.
Bureacracy re: policies, procedures, etc. is extremely thick and not streamlined.

review_title: Cisco as a whole, is a Good company.  Their internal education organization is a big disappointment
job_title: Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Bonuses
Work From Home Flexibility
Salary is competitive
cons:
Favoritism runs high, especially in HR
Education organization has a lot to be desired.  Cisco appoints its 1st Chief Learning Officer after 25 years -- The person has no education domain expertise and is an ineffective leader (As demonstrated by the external assessment conducted on the leadership team).  Evaluation Results: Ineffective across the board.
Highly political.  For HR, leadership is selected based on who you know and not your skill set.  Reference: Senior VP of HR leaves to pursue better opportunity.  VP underneath him leaves to pursue better opportunity -- Both were very good leaders, and very capable.  Remaining HR leadership (including the internal education VP/CLO: A big disappointment

review_title: Just another big company with average benefits and pay
job_title: Sales in Raleigh, NC
pros: Company is financial stable and continues to make money each quarter.  The company's benefits are competitive. Working at a larger site comes with extra perks like free gym membership.
cons: It is very difficult to get things done internally because the company is SO large. The company has recently laid off some of its workforce, but it continues to add Sr VPs.  Career advancement and salary increases are hard to come by - unless you are at the top!  The company's stock has been flat for years, and the amount of RSAs that are given is insultingly low.

review_title: Awesome.....experience
job_title: Software Engineer III in Bangalore
pros:
Good/Great place to work. However it bot depends on the BU too. Company gives priority on quality and not quantitative work and respects employees for their doing. Recruitment are strictly done on requirement and hence if qualified will have maximum chance of getting work for what you were recruited for and for what you were recruited for ? Highly dependents on quality engineers than on management

Great perks, focal incentives to keep employees happy and plus lot of other benefits like car lease etc. WFH is allowed and hence even with high working pressure environment, balancing life with work becomes quite reasonable.
Would love to join back..given an opportunities that matches my skills
cons:
Lot of Business Transition/Acquisition can be little hurdle at times when things are moved as per decision from Higher Management w/o much of knowledge. 
Internal movement even though supported as policy is not willingly accepted by managers always

review_title: Really ungrateful
job_title: Technical Writer in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco is a cash cow in terms of compensation as compared to other companies I have worked for. They just keep finding new ways to compensate you, which is fantastic.
cons: The group I worked in was full of really nasty and stuck-up people. If you had a new idea, nobody was interested. Ours was simply to follow, not to ever question. I had the impression that I didn't have the right employee grade to have any opinions. Not sure if this was true in other groups and it may have been simply that if the idea was from me, the manager had no interest. Frankly, I cannot say enough bad things about most of the people I worked with. Cross-functionally though the people were fine, smart, helpful.

review_title: Slow agonizing decline
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Work-life balance is the last remaining pro.
cons: I worked at Cisco for over 10 years and have seen the company go from a great, creative, energetic place to work to a place people just do the bare minimum to get by. Career opportunity is limited to those in management and those who can tow the line in company politics. Work-life balance is the last real remaining benefit, so what you get is a bunch of people who only care about that and have stopped caring about quality of work. Management is made up of a bunch of sell-outs who tote the great "family values" culture, but have no qualm about laying off good people to save a buck or two. If you get stay at Cisco for more than a few years, expect your pay to lag market rates.

review_title: Great experience, great development and rewarding under the right management team
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
The freedom is performing you job, this includes the flexibility of working from home or any office and the responsibilities of time and expense management. 

The company puts a lot of trust in you as an individual contributor. 

The biggest plus are your coworkers and the support you receive and contribute to them.
cons:
If you are unfortunate with a poor manager that you report to can make the job a challenge, but you can meet him/her  prior to taking a position reporting to him/her.

The raises and promotions are a bit too few and too far apart, but the ability to work from home saves on many expenses.

review_title: Decent Company to work for
job_title: Technical Leader in Milpitas, CA
pros: Challenging work.  Extensive types of work and job skills available.  Good benefits:  medical, 401K, ESPP, incentive stock awards.
cons:
In my area it is almost impossible to transfer out to another group.  Huge amount of processes/overhead as a software developer you have to jump over to commit any code.  When joining, very difficult to get more experienced engineers to help to learn the tools, router mgmt/sw install, etc..  You're on your own for learning most things on the job.

The company culture is stale, not going to be too attractive for you.  Your enjoyment/fulfillment from working at Cisco will mostly come from your own group and your manager.  Probably true for most companies.

review_title: Smart people, great leadership and fun projects
job_title: Technical Leader in Raleigh, NC
pros: Folks at Cisco are top notch.  They are self motivated, do the right thing and come up with ingenious ideas.  The large size of the company and shear # of products give you great opportunity to work on what you want.
cons: There are some bad apples in the large crowd of people.  Be sure when you interview to talk to the folks you will be working with and especially feel out your direct manager to see if style, personality and values match.

review_title: Good Company, with a huge user base
job_title: Software Engineer IV in Ottawa, ON
pros: An excellent company to learn routing, switching and computer networks.   Interesting work.   Many opportunities to learn and apply technology.  Cisco's following in the Networking field is widespread and equal to none, making it a very nice addition to the resume..   -Many opportunities to innovate.  Good compensation,  Good benefits,  A flexible work environment.
cons: Recently there have been  too many senseless changes in direction causing turmoil.  Too many layers of middle managers and vice presidents imposing their own personal agendas on the development and engineering groups,

review_title: Great place to work
job_title: Business Analyst in Kraków
pros:
[related to Cracow] Very vibrant environment and predominance of young people.
Amazing flexibility on work hours and place. Independence in your tasks planning. Friendly atmosphere. Satisfying benefits and very well planned office.
cons: Sometimes the work-life balance ten to be... unbalanced. The team is sometimes lacking actual leader, despite the manager presence. Due to the constant changes and lack of some processes it tends to be a bit chaotic and challenging (which also can be an advantage).

review_title: Excellent culture and technology leader in Internet world.
job_title: Manager, HW Engineering in San Jose, CA
pros: Innovative company for networking industry.  Continuous learning opportunity for both technical and leadership skills.  Excellent culture in giving back to community.  All employees are allowed to spend upto 5 days (paid time off) to give back to community as volunteer.  Cisco is the industry leaders in multiple areas in Routing/Switching/Server/Data Center.  Very stable company.  Lots of learning opportunities as company encourage to rotate the job functions within the company.  And great benefits including 4 weeks of paid PTOs can be used for vacation or sick leave.
cons: Company is big and sometimes it took long time to make a decision.  Process oriented company and it can be rigid sometimes.  Sometimes it can be good.  Sometime it can play as downside.  Other than that, Cisco is a great company to work and learn.

review_title: Customer Success Manager review
job_title: Customer Success Manager in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
Cisco really stimulates and empower employees for their personal and professional development. The company heavily invest in training to give you the knowledge and tools to enable you to excel in your role. It is a solid company with great compensation and benefits compared to other companies within the same market. Good work-life balance. Management stimulates and accepts open and honest feedback.
Customer success at Cisco is the best place to be. A lot is happening and changing, there are many learning and career opportunities. The impact I make is clear, measurable and rewarded.
cons:
Data accuracy might be an issue (multiple sources of information). 
Delivery processes getting in the way of things that needs to be done for our customers.

review_title: Not the company it once was
job_title: Software Engineer in Galway
pros:
Working with the latest technologies 
Lots of fund raising and community work 
Some very talented people
Ample car parking
cons:
Lack of career progression in recent years (common opinion shared by many)
Little or no budget for pay rises or promotions 
Work life balance is not great
Not using employees skills adequately 
Located in an industrial business park, not easily accessible to Oranmore town centre without driving
Lack of catering options in the immediate area - on-site canteen does best with resources it has
Frequent redundancies at a company level
Often feels like you get rewarded for implementing things quick and buggy rather than slow and correct the first time

review_title: Benefits of working at Cisco as a woman employee
job_title: Senior Technical Writer in Bangalore
pros:
- Women-friendly workplace ambience
- Flexible work hours
- Creche in office campus
- In-campus facilities like clinic, ATMs, cafe, gym, indoor games, etc helps save time in traveling and getting things done in the Campus
- Clean & hygienic restrooms with sanitary napkin dispensers and safe disposal systems
- Safety of women employees by ensuring that they don't leave unaccompanied after late hours at office
cons:
- Reduced awareness of challenges faced by working mothers to maintain a healthy work/life balance
- Bias against women employees in the forms of inadvertent sexist remarks. This discourages women employees from bringing their best selves to work and encourages more instances of such behavior

review_title: Great flexibility but politics and poor management are worsening, and a lot of fat in org
job_title: Marketing Communications in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexibility, dedication to customers, mission, potential to impact the world
cons: Toooooo many reorgs, politics decide who gets promoted, a lot of bad mid- and senior- level managers who have zero ability to lead, serious ageism pushing senior talent out to make room for new recruits. Also too much fat in the org (too many people doing too much overlapping work that don't necessarily move the business).

review_title: We're #1, No really!
job_title: Technical Consulting Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: The work-life balance is superb.  I am a mother of 3 and as an engineer I have a great team and great company that support me especially when the unexpected happens or I need to leave.  The execs are so supportive and are easily reachable which is surprising to me considering the size of the company.  I just always imagined the execs would be so busy and wouldn't really interact with those of us who are lower in the company.  How wrong could I be?  They are so down to earth and always willing to talk and to help in any way.
cons: Sometimes it may be hard to figure out how to advance in a company so big so I'd just say to always talk with management about your goals and get a mentor that will help you as well.

review_title: Good place to work between companies of this size and maturity
job_title: Technical Leader I  in San Jose, CA
pros: Being a relatively big company and including a great number of different business units Cisco offers lots of opportunities to be exposes to different technologies. As an financially successful company Cisco offers stability and nice (but not great) compensation and benefits package. Between so big number of employees it is easy to find many of really smart ones though the average level is not that high.
cons: Cisco is devoting lots of focus to protecting legacy products and, in some sense, it puts breaks to innovation drive and presents some inertia of thinking. Managers are generally competent technically but the level of politics vs. awards for taking rsk for the decision makes managers to go on the safe side.

review_title: Cisco is a mixed bag.
job_title: Technical Leader in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco has great benefits and is phenomenal at promoting flexible work.  Cisco empowers employees to innovate and be creative; to take charge of finding solutions for problems.  If you are a self starter it is easy to have an interesting job.
cons: There are a HUGE amount of politics going on.  Secrets, backstabbing, unfair promotions.  It is a very competitive environment.  Some groups have way too much process and others not enough.  It's easy to get lost in the shuffle.

review_title: Cisco - Flawed but Still One of the Best
job_title: Program Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros: This is a very good company to work for as far as large corporations go. People are generally treated with respect (although there are always exceptions) and the culture is nice - teamwork oriented, etc. The benefits are pretty good.
cons: No regular raises since 2001 - it is possible to get "equity adjustments" but very difficult. Even top performers tend to go a year or two between these "adjustments." In terms of salary, loyalty is not rewarded - it is very common for Cisco to hire externally at higher pay grades than the internal people who have been there for a long time - and the external hires do not necessarily have more experience overall.

review_title: You really don't want to work here for a long time
job_title: Program Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: Cisco had some good medical benefits, but they went away.  They had a good stock option plan, but that went to the mangers and the senior leadership team.  They had a good stock grant plan when you got promoted, but that is all under water and can't remember when I had a promotion in 7 years.
cons: It's like reality TV, let's have another re-org to protect the management or give someone more people to build their empire.  To many Directors who produce nothing.  There are managers who have no reports to manage.  It's not what you know or do, it's how much your boss enjoys your company.   Cisco would make an excellent Survival TV show.  Or maybe not, no one would belive the nonsense that goes on here.

review_title: Great company, great Technical Leaders
job_title: Software Engineer II in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco's TLs will floor you with their humility despite the wealth of knowledge and insight they carry. For a Grade 4-6, the learning can be phenomenal if tuned properly.  John Chambers is an amazing CEO - such a great visionary. He has lead Cisco steadfast through difficult times and given focus/resources to the right areas to solve Customer problems.
cons: Execution maybe ? Given the size of Cisco, it is hard to disagree that things move relatively slower at Cisco than at other smaller companies in the same domain. It can get annoying to a Cisco employee when "spin-ins" are funded despite the treasure trove of technical expertise and ability to execute within. Fixing this malaise could potentially work wonders!

review_title: Good workplace with reasonable compensation & benefits
job_title: Senior Software QA Engineer in Bangalore
pros: Good infrastructure, good work environment, decent employee friendly policies, decent salary which may not be the best in the industry but definitely above average for that industry, decent work-life balance, personal experience of good ethical managers.
cons: Personal experience that the team that I worked in didn't have anything technically very novel or innovative to learn from. As a big organization, standards, policies and bureaucracies creep in which do take up your valuable time, so the excitement and visibility seen in a startup like environment will not be present.

review_title: Company trying to Re-invent itself
job_title: Manager, Software Development in Lawrenceville, GA
pros:
- Competitive salary with good bonus plan puts them towards the high end of the pay scale
- Most teams allow flex-time and working from home when needed
- Excellent collaboration tools to support workers
cons:
- Annual lay-offs (6 out of last 7 years) at end of fiscal year (July)
- Frequent re-organizations
- Burdensome/rigid processes and design leverage from previous products stifle creativity and new approaches

review_title: great co-workers
job_title: Software Engineer II in Boxborough, MA
pros: Great co-workers, great place to learn, great environment, great benefits, overall lots of fun day to day. Lots of good outings as well.
cons: terrible bureaucracy. and lack of pay and respect for their employees long term careers. So much transition that helps benefit them short term but is deceiving for long term benefits to the company

review_title: Cisco H1B Systems
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Plenty of new technology and challenges.  Worked with many great team members over the years at Cisco. Always had more work than I could do in advanced services.
Work from home, virtual office.
cons:
Experience means little, they will replace anyone they can with younger, cheaper or H1B import.  
No time to get training on the new technology. 
Constantly changing product direction, often driven by acquisition justification.
50 hour weeks are common place, and they still want you to rack up Cisco certifications in your spare time.

review_title: Cisco Has Lost Its Way
job_title: Senior Director in San Jose, CA
pros: Laser focus on customers-partners has always been embedded in the company's DNA.
cons: Constant layoffs-  dismissing senior technical talent who are loved by their customers  and/or are recognized in the industry; gross mis-steps in cloud;  a toxic environment of fear has set into various organizations because of these sudden dismissals especially when the company is profitable.  As one would assess a product for fair trade, I strongly believe the treatment of people should be a factor in determining whether or not one wishes to do business with the company. Should you work at the company -- go for a very very short ride only. As a shareholder - I am deeply concerned.

review_title: Good place for working women
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bangalore
pros: Flat, non hierarchical culture. Focus on outcomes - "what you deliver" rather than hours spent in the office. Flexible culture with high trust from management on working remotely, as long as you continue to deliver well. Very strong benefits, particularly healthcare, insurances and leave policies. Good work environment - relatively low politics and management at the Director and up levels is pretty high calibre
cons: Typical large company issues - bureacracy in getting things done, many people oly willing to work within the narrow silos of their jobs and not stretch beyond. Pay cycles are unpredictable and increase amounts can be below the market.

review_title: Toxic political culture
job_title: Senior Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Great place to learn the art of Product  Management. You get a very rounded experience of all aspects and get significant ownership of a product, not just its pieces. Cisco trained Product managers do very well in the industry. Work life balance is good.
cons: Cisco pays lesser than Bay Area average. The Service Provider Networking Group I worked in was simply political and toxic. Favoritism and clique culture was rife. Things were done simply to make people feel bad. I was also discriminated against because I was a woman with a voice and an opinion. I used to hear stories of  how the "old boys gang" used to get together over drinks and trash the women in the team.

review_title: Cisco is rock solid, but lacks inspired innovation
job_title: Software Engineering Intern I in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Excellent work environment, casual but demanding
- The Cisco name:  the king of networking
- A very solid, stable company, without any really aggressive competition
- Plenty of paid time off
cons:
- As an intern, I have observed that the work week can be extremely long for full time employees, and this type of time commitment is expected when customer issues arise (some members of my team just put in a 100 hour work week)
- There is some flexibility with work/life balance in that you can work a 40-hour week if you get your job done and can choose when you come to work and leave, but if you expect any type of promotion, work must be your life
- Too many constraints and stringent processes causes a lack of innovation and creativity

review_title: Not what it used to be
job_title: in Raleigh, NC
pros: There are still some great people at Cisco, although because of process and politics the people don't have the ability to influence change like they used to.  You can learn a great deal from the people who have been around for a while.
cons: There are hundreds of directors at Cisco with no reports.  The company is so executive and management heavy that its mind boggling.  They have also placed a bet on outsourcing many functions, and as a result its difficult to get even the simplest tasks performed by anyone competent.

review_title: Was a great company, now it become less and less attractive
job_title: Technical Lead in San Jose, CA
pros: flexible work time. Gym and day care center. Every building has a shower room. Work load is relatively light if you are an above average person. Lots of internal openings in different group, different technology.
cons: Could easily get comfortable and laid back, not learning new things, lost competence to the outside world.  Lots of talent and smart people are leaving the company.  More and more average Joes joined.  Lots of managers, directors, and VPs. Too much middle layer management.  Product quality is getting lower and lower.  Most of the time, it is because managers are focusing on product releases and adding new features, without giving time for product internal structure improvement.

review_title: Simply Hopeless. Too much politics. People work to keep their job.
job_title: Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexibility to work remotely makes a huge difference.
cons:
Perhaps this was the most nightmarish experience I have had in a big company. It's sad that Cisco had such fat cats sitting and just taking bad decisions for business to suit their personal ambitions for promotion.

Politics and lack of people with proper skills  - that should sum it up. Nobody really cares about doing good work. All they care is "how do I keep my manager happy" so they can keep their job.

New ideas are shot down and people who voice their opinion are shown the door out.

review_title: Good benefits, average pay, very beaucratic
job_title: Technical Lead in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Medical Insurance is excellent
- Bonuses are very good
- Pay is great for engineers with average or below average skills
- Company policies are very liberal
cons:
- Bonuses and restricted stock are the only way that the company distinguishes high performers from the rest. So, it pays to be a an average or below average performer. Employees being fired for poor performance is very very rare.
- Product revenues almost don't matter. Which causes complete lack of alignment in teams, causing some to focus only on personal growth and the rest to not focus at all
- Teams are overstaffed, causing obvious fallouts like low accountability, poor quality, high level of politics and inefficiency and complete misuse of benefits (like working from home).

review_title: Being acquired by Cisco was an eye-opener
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Remote/mobile work is enhanced by the variety of collaboration technology available, even from your phone. Investment in infrastructure like employee directory and purchasing website are impressive. Onsite health clinic and services, encouragement to be active, etc. is great.
cons: Having worked at Intel for 16 years, I know what it is like to work at a big company but being acquired by Cisco was a real eye-opener. There is such a large staff and so many contractors, you've got a choice: grab on and hold tight, be an overlap, or be laid-back.  Although this exists in many companies, Cisco is the poster child.

review_title: Horrible big corporate
job_title: Product Engineer in Denver, CO
pros: Inflated salaries, excellent benefits, good PTO time.
cons: Endless red tape. Overly PC. Bad bad middle management. No room for growth. Extensive layoffs. Your contribution is not appreciated but rather you are a number and easily replaced.

review_title: Was excellent, still good for a big company
job_title: Director in San Jose, CA
pros:
- One can work in some of the latest technologies in networking, Data Center etc.
- Very good work culture
- Allows good work life balance
- Good compensation
cons:
- Lost it's sheen a one of the best company to work for.
- All the good technical talent left the company.
- Completely operations-focused upper management is driving away what ever little talent left in the company.
- No strong leader(s) who knows the technology.

review_title: Bad Impact
job_title: Software Engineer II in Bangalore
pros: Good Salary, nice perks, pantry is good. Food also provided. Good technologies to work and learn.
cons: Many.... Team members are not friendly. Especially the contract employees have to learn how to behave with co workers. Some team managers are just not worth being in that position. In the name of Agile SCRUM, they restrict the team member's movements inside the office premises. There is no one to help the newly joined. If any newbie stuck with something, they will never get prompt help. Blind HRs, they never worry about the employee's welfare. I personally facing huge disappointment in my team. Huge kannada impact in my team. Very bad way of treating the team member.

review_title: Incredible Company Overall
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Milpitas, CA
pros:
-Awesome people
-Great work/life balance
-Flexible hours
-Ability to work from home
-Really amazing benefits (the most comprehensive healthcare I've ever had)
-A nice bonus when the company is doing well
-Management truly cares about my development and growth
cons:
-Due to Cisco being a very large company, sometimes a lot of bureaucracy and politics
-Sometimes slow pace of execution and adaptation - once again due to being a large company (Cisco is going through a lot of effort to improve this though)
-Can be challenging to move up, sometimes promotion is based on politics (more so about who you know as opposed to your merit/achievements)

review_title: Sr Product Manager
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
Lots of smart people around
Great company to learn how to handle complex business problems
Very flexible work culture even when you have lots of deliverables to handle
Competitive salary if you do not compare it to the top 5% highest paying companies in the valley
cons:
Cisco is in the middle of lots of leadership changes; lots of confusion around company direction
Switching business, which is 1/3rd the entire companies business is going through a lot of confusion

review_title: Good company/people, but slow on many fronts
job_title: Business Development Manager in London, England
pros:
Good compensation,benefits, working environment. 
Generally great people - never short of an expert, or help.
Good balance for freedom of role and autonomy.
cons:
Lots of politics
Very slow career progress...sideways can be ok, but upwards extremely slow and difficult
Lots of layers of management - arguably too many vs individual contributors. 
Still very much a Box shifter - transition to solutions / software is slow. Still has an infrastructure heavy mindset.
Slow changes/decision making. 
Company Strategy not quick to respond to market transitions, or be executed quickly enough
Annual "Restructure", morale is not great. No position is safe, and executed rather randomly without backing up the rationale behind the restructure in place first.
Redundancy Settlement packages are very poor for such a respected organisation, leaving many with a bad feeling.

review_title: Morale is lower each year
job_title: Senior Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexible work location, life/work balance, good amount of PTO, sometimes a decent bonus.  Some very smart people, and some decent managers.  Loads of training available.  Can be challenging work.
cons: Morale gets lower each year, huge layoffs every year in August.  Lot's of people looking over their shoulders.  Very top heavy too many managers/directors etc, not enough rank and file which gets depleted more and more each year.  Company can't decide what it is anymore:  a networking company or a security company, or if they should try to buy yet another cloud based startup in an attempt to catch up with competition.

review_title: Shaping the future in Customer Success
job_title: Customer Success Manager in London, England
pros: A dynamic, growing part of Cisco which is at forefront of the company's transition to a software company. Working in Customer Success gives me real opportunity to make a real difference to Customer and Partners alike. It is also great to be part of one of the brightest, most diverse, fun and growing groups within Cisco.
cons: Sometimes feels like we are growing to fast for our business and our processes and tools are playing catch up- but I am confident that will be fixed imminently. Additionally, some parts of our business just don't get Customer Success and are stuck in the past regarding Selling Motions

review_title: Great Culture
job_title: Systems Engineer in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: Cisco is a company where one can start a career and it could last a lifetime provided you choose to keep moving as the company has so much to offer in terms of technology architectures, roles offered and some really smart people to help you along the way. It offers very good benefits and everybody is very focussed around helping customers. It takes good care of its employees and that directly shows up when everybody cares so much about the customer. One of the best pay masters in India in IT. Good work life balance. Micro-management is not encouraged, unless you ask for it :-)
cons: The frequent layoffs can be challenging, however it is part of the game.

review_title: Great Place to Work in general but...
job_title: Project Manager in Kraków
pros:
*Many development opportunities - you can take more work, responsibility or make a lateral move
*Great people
*Nice office
*Many activities that you can participate in (apart from work)
*Great and stable place to work in general if you are satisfied with your terms and work type
*volunteering opportunities
cons:
*Difficult to get a fair salary increase or promotion
*No career development program for talents

review_title: Cisco Austin is a Crap shoot
job_title: Engineering Manager in Austin, TX
pros: Worked for Cisco for over 10 years the best I can say Benefits are good.
cons:
Worked for Cisco for over 10 years the best I can say Benefits are good.
In Cisco Austin it is a crap shoot depending on the Business unit your team might be part off. Cisco Austin is practically a satellite  location with the teams having  to report elsewhere.  So too much uncertainty 
Too political
Too many re-orgs 
Pressure from leadership to work extended hours, I have seen some engineers work through the night
Since Cisco is not investing heavily in Austin, they don't allow teams to grow locally. You will be under the gun to work almost daily and off hours with offshore resource in India and other low cost centers in Eastern Europe.
Business leadership in SJ always pushing for moving work offshore.

review_title: Cisco: At least it's better than Yahoo
job_title: Sales in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco has different vibes at each of its offices, which makes it nice if you don't like the culture at the place you're working at. I personally find the San Jose offices to be very stuffy. RTP is my favorite because the people are great and more laid back.
cons: At times it's so corporate that all decision making goes at snail speed. People talk about John Chambers and that's about it. There's no room for going outside the box and finding new ways of doing things, everyone sticks to what they know and does it.

review_title: Cisco has the potential to be a very good place to work, but may be in a layoff - underperforming spiral.
job_title: Hardware Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
*  Used to work with many talented people.  Many of the seasoned professionals were allowed to leave to our competitors while we paid them a year's salary.
*  Fair compensation
*  Fair work hours with good work/life balance.
cons:
*  You won't get rich working at Cisco
*  With most managers having 8-14 reports and raises focused on the top 25%, you won't be receiving raises on a regular basis.

review_title: Still a good company, but times have changed while senior leadership has not
job_title: Senior Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexibility in how/where you work. You can rely on executive level support in the case of serious family/health issues. Some of the culture is still intact, but you have to search for it and is manager dependent.
cons: It's a big company now with big company issues. Tenure of senior level executives tends to drive decision making based on relationships vs. market issues/company needs. More accountability needs to be placed on the executives and we need to get away from multiple levels of executives reporting to each other.

review_title: Great Company, Hard Work.
job_title: Program Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: You'll never get bored working at Cisco and there are always new opportunities to chose from.  If you take advantage of the internal "Glide" program, you can transfer horizontally to another job role (such as from Engineer over to Project Manager).  Not many companies offer that kind of flexibility.
cons: The work is hard and the hours can be very long.  The pay is on the high end of average for this industry, but you won't get rich off of your base pay.  Cisco is a meritocracy where contribution is rewarded (both by peers and by managers).  Also, if the company does well, the annual bonuses can be quite nice.

review_title: Great place to work, strong future outlook
job_title: Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Strong work/life balance, Opportunity to work remotely, Improved market position in collaboration, Large organization but trying to bring in agile/startup culture and renovating a lot of the HQ offices with open floor spaces, etc. Would recommend working here to others.
cons:
Large organization still in the process of becoming more agile, so the bureaucracy and slow pace can be a hinderance at times. 
Many Cisco lifers are passionate about what they're working on, but some seem to be along for the ride, only to do the minimal amount of work necessary (I'm sure most large companies experience this). 
Lots of senior leadership changes in recent years leads to frequent strategic changes and internal bickering at times.

review_title: Trying Hard to Get Its Groove Back
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Great work/life balance, ability to work from home or work a flexible schedule. Great benefits (401K match, decent salary/bonus, ESPP, medical benefits, PTO, etc.). Brand name company with global recognition. If you're under 30, you'll be lavished with attention and promotion.
cons: Lots of instability due to quarterly restructuring. Poor mid-level managers who have been at Cisco for eons and are more concerned with managing up. Very passive aggressive culture. No annual review process -- if you're manager is weak, you will not be recognized for achievements. Layers of VPs who talk a good game but are poor on execution.

review_title: Operations Manager
job_title: Business Operations Manager in Victoria, BC
pros: Love the dynamic market we work in, the intelligent leadership, the drive for success and Pay - for Performance philosophy, the smart people I get to work with, the flexible work environment, the focus on family priorities outside of work, and the collaborative and highly mobile technology we get to use as employees which enables a very mobile and engaged workforce.  The pay and benefits package is also great.
cons:
To be a top performer you need to work pretty hard to emerge above the pack of already top performers, but it's nice to work with such a talented group and to be pushed that hard. You also have to be pretty disciplined otherwise you can work 24x7.

As a large company change is slow in some pockets but fast in others. We're working hard to increase our corporate agility.

review_title: Analyst business operation - awesome experience
job_title: Analyst Business Operation in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
Opportunity to work with international team , opportunity to training and develop your hardskills 
Great opportunity to involve in a large projects.
Salary is above of the industry . 
The benefits such as health insurance is the best of the Country . And it’s the same for all positions if you are  blue badge contract (non tird-part)
cons:
There is no chance to start one international carrier , it’s so hard to reach one interview on internal position . 
Most of employee that moved to U,S It was due the network that gave a chance to reach an international relocation ..

review_title: Great Place to Work
job_title: Technical Leader in Bangalore
pros:
Depending on the Team, the technology you work on differs, but there is a great push to adopt new tech. Also there are many internal openings in various domains. 
The Campus is awesome, food delicious(not free but via food coupons) and lots of sports and relaxation facilities.
They are very transparent about the Bonus component and you can be assured that your immediate manager cannot misguide you on how much you are supposed to get since the company performance figures are publicly shared.
Transport facilities are really nice.
cons:
Hikes might be bit disheartening if you are a top performer.
Cisco does regular layoffs of entire orgs if they do not perform over a period of time. This might be a issue of concern if you land up in an underperforming product.
However the layoff compensation is quite adequate and one of the best in the industry.

review_title: No Better Place to Start Your Career
job_title: Associate Sales Representative (CSAP) in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Cisco overall is an amazing company with an unbeatable culture and work-life balance. It can be difficult to navigate a company like Cisco with such large and sometimes-siloed functions, but everyone is so open to knowledge-sharing and helping with internal movement. After spending 2 great years in Marketing, I realized I wanted to work in Cisco Sales, and recruited into CSAP (Cisco Sales Associate Program),

CSAP itself is a world-class training program with unmatched opportunities for career progression for talent so early in career. I couldn't recommend it highly enough to anyone in college looking to step into tech sales after graduation.
cons: Overwhelmingly complex products & solutions, as well as internal processes. Some of these issues are just a result of being such a large company and are not unique to Cisco, but Cisco definitely knows how to overcomplicate things.

review_title: Flexible Working, Intelligent people, exciting culture, endless possibilities
job_title: Marketing Manager in London, England
pros:
- A truly flexible working culture. You can work anywhere at anytime- but if they are flexible, you need to be flexible too
- Great pay and career opportunities. Cisco always gives you (and encourages) you to try new roles/ paths
- Intelligent and passionate people with great vision from VPs/ Execs
cons:
Not a con but more of a side note- you get all the above cons but are expected to work hard and give it your all.  

Another thing I have noticed is there does seem to be a yearly 'restructuring' where quite a few redundancies are made to remove bottom 10%. Then shortly after there will be a mass hiring of new talent (although this may be a positive to remove slackers and keep an energised workforce)

review_title: Good place to gain experience (entry level)
job_title: IT Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Big company, which maybe translate to job security, and lots of places to move within, but very hard if you get screwed by your manager. Cisco is a good place if you are entry level and you want to work for 2-4 years to gain some experience. Promotion is bit difficult but if you work hard you can be promoted also depends on your manager
cons: Too many contractors from infosys and similar companies that have no idea what the hell they are doing! You have be butt buddies with your manager to get ranked high in the performance. Some of them very political and give priority to people like them. For example indians only give good recommendation to other indians... very disappointing!

review_title: Good place to learn, hard to work there for a long time.
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Learned a lot about how multinationals work
- I was challenged to do things I never thought I could do (and I was successful!)
cons:
- Work never ended.  Because I was in a position where I had to work with people in locations worldwide, I had to be available almost 24/7.
- Extremely competitive.  Lots of politics.
- It was so big that I had no idea of what was going on in many parts of the company.
- Frugality can be a good thing, but they take it too far.

review_title: WAS a great place to work -
job_title: Product Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Decent pay, decent benefits, work/life balance is poor in sales
cons: Has become very political and full of managers with very poor people skills. Cisco no longer cares about its people or the entrepreneurial spirit that once thrived in all of us and took the company so far. Very hard to move up in the organization - many talented people are leaving or being let go because of poor management.  Cisco was good to me for many years but it is no longer the company I loved so much.

review_title: Chambers needs to go
job_title: Account Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Strong teaming environment regarding collaboration.  Lots of technology at your fingertips and open to working remotely/at a distance.
cons: No one lifts a finger unless they are compensated on it - and there are a lot of 'grey areas' where people aren't paid on things - so use your power of persuasion to ask for help.  You can absolutely fall victim of your own success and middle mgmt will not easily allow you to promote out if you are a solid performer on their teams.

review_title: Cisco is a good place to work.  Layoff  yearly.
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Still market leader in networking as it struggles with sluggish sales and a range of fierce competitors.

- A good place to work with talented engineers/managers, 4 weeks PTO etc. if computer networking is your passion.
cons:
- A giant engineering organization, lack of diversity in Bay Area.  There are good managers and immature managers. It depends on your luck after reorganization or management change average 12-18 months.

- Consecutive layoff yearly (or outsourcing jobs to cheaper countries). The company laid off 6,000 job  in 2014, or roughly 8 percent of its workforce, and has trimmed nearly 20,000 jobs over the past five years.

review_title: Ideal job before you retire
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
You can pretty much work as much as you want, beyond a minimal threshold. Cisco can be very relaxed. Depends on your team (some teams work all the time, including weekends). My team had people working 20 hour weeks. I had friends who did 4 hour weeks. 
Work from home.
Cab service.
Friendly culture and people.
Lot of opportunities to learn networking, albeit Cisco proprietary stuff.
cons:
There's no innovation whatsoever. This is not a macro level problem. It reflects on your job.
Work is extremely repetitive. 
Lot of complacency and red-tape.
Once you get stuck to your role, its hard to do something else or change pace.
Frequent layoffs and reorgs. Nobody hears about the reorgs in the news, but they probably have worse effects than the layoffs.

review_title: Too much politics
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Still have a lot of talents and responsible engineers and customer advocates. Benefits are still fairly competitive.
cons:
There is a culture that everyone likes to trace or get associated with the "next big thing". In effect, often times there are multiple teams doing the same thing. And then, it becomes ugly as to who should stay. 

A ripple effect is that there are little accountability. Projects are often offloaded to India and then quality takes a deep dive. Support is often lacking because they simply didn't have the complete picture. Bugs are often closed or workarounded instead of fixed at the root.

review_title: Terrible Work/Life Balance
job_title: QA ETL Manager in Carlsbad, CA
pros:
benefits are alright though most start past 6 months
pay is good
looks good on resumé
cons:
