job_title: Marketing in San Jose, CA
pros: Smart people, decent pay and benefits.
cons: Very siloed positions, most people are under-employed since very talented people are hired into job silos that limit the full expression or development of their skills.  There are constant layoffs, accompanied by all of the unhealthy cultural by-products that come with layoffs: paranoia, lack of motivation, managers pitching smoke-and-mirror programs since you will never be held accountable to deliver based on the constant reorganizations and priority shifts, lack of trust.  Very talented senior leaders who have the confidence to speak the truth, name the dysfunction for what it is, and try to be agents for change are always the ones to announce they are 'pursuing other opportunities' (aka, forced out), leaving the sub-par leaders to run the ship.

review_title: Great place to work at!! Tech writer with Cisco for the last 10 years!!
job_title: Technical Writer in Bangalore
pros:
1) Flexibility: Have work from home options and work hours that can be balanced between home and office. This allows me to spend time for self-care and family, apart from focusing on my career.
2) Beautiful campus and added facilities
3) Management is always ready to listen 
4) Compensation and other benefits such as, leave of absence, etc
cons: The recent layoffs have triggered a fear of insecurity with the job. However, Cisco takes utmost care to ensure that the employees who are impacted are taken good care in terms of the benefits.  This cannot be compared with the other organizations. Although these decisions are difficult for Cisco, it tries its level best to compensate in the best manner possible.

review_title: Reorgs can't mask bad management forever.
job_title: Serviceability Design Engineer in Richardson, TX
pros: The attitude of "customer success" is very prevalent within the company, so if you run up against a roadblock, using that magic phrase opens many doors.
cons: In Customer Advocacy, there were no real opportunities for advancement unless you were willing to relocate to San Jose.  Benefit costs increased substantially every year, but there were no raises to be had.  Reorganization happened every 6 months, so I never had the same boss for one full review cycle.  Management was constantly trying to justify the existence of our group by adding supplemental job tasks to the job description, but failing to recognize and evangelize the inherent value of our core deliverables.

review_title: Cisco rocks
job_title: Systems Engineer III in Toronto, ON
pros: You are working with talented and driven peers in a  highly collaborative environment. The management team is very supportive of employee training and development, allowing employees to learn and grow with the company.  Cisco has a culture of employee empowerment, giving employees the freedom to make important decisions.
cons: Long hours and job strain can take toll on personal life. Need to find better work-life balance for employees.  Though the company expects its employees to perform in the industry's top 10% but its compensation plans for the systems engineers is only above average.

review_title: Worst Sales Management I have ever had the displeasure to work with
job_title: Enterprise Account Manager in Overland Park, KS
pros:
Brand is highly regarded
Install Base typically leads to long term customer relationships
Always able to get audience with customer executives.
cons:
What John Chamber's preaches is not reality in the trenches.  Sales Management are spreadsheet jockeys who are manic and frankly, emotionally frazzled by their fear of upper management.  I likened my experience in sales to the attributes of 3rd generation child abuse.  You manager was abused by his manager, so he abuses you because it is the "way I was raised".  A total lack of management ethics when the heat is on to hit a sales commit at the end of a month or a quarter.

My advice is to not be seduced by the "Human Network" but stay away from Cisco for your "Human Sanity"

review_title: Horrible bureaucracy for managers
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Interesting group of people, working on good technology.

Good sense of long-term vision by the execs.

General culture of being willing to take risks on new technology.
cons:
Bureaucracy for anyone trying to hire people, buy captial equipment, or add a vendor to the approved vendors list is horrible.

Inter-team petty politics, particularly by some Support managers, is a pain.

Strategy seems to change too frequently to be able to implement effectively.

Too many people in different customer advocacy roles just trying to justify their own jobs.

review_title: Probably the company with the highest IQ I've ever workedat
job_title: IT Analyst in Raleigh, NC
pros: Competitive pay, good benefits and the advantages of contributing in a world-class, world-leading institution. Most management is flexible and focused on results. Definite benefit to working in California but the good news is that the mentality is slowly changing and telecommuting is more and more accepted. A case of "eating your own dog food" since Cisco sells the technologies that allow for remote work. Had I not have a family illness I needed to tend to I'd still be there.
cons: Has lost some of the agility as it has grown. There are some people who still cling to the past rather than work at making today and tomorrow better. When I was there they were moving to the open concept work space

review_title: Wonderful company to start you career straight out of college.
job_title: IT Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Cisco has a bunch of perks; Flexibility, Growth, Exposure, Work/Life Balance, Great Atmosphere, Work Family. Overall Cisco cares about their employees and what makes them happy.
cons: Cisco only has a couple of negatives in my opinion. Performance reviews are slightly unfair but don't really harm you(meaning you are more likely to get average but that means good). Visiting HQ depends upon the team you work for and some teams never send people some limits visibility face to face (WebEx makes up for that a little but still would like to shake a hand from time to time.)

review_title: Enjoyed solving many critical issues to help the company transform. However zero recognition or reward for the success.
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Like the company's management by objective (MBO) culture, assuming everyone's MBOs align. Do love the company's acceptance of a distributed (work anywhere) culture. Do support the company's latest "Internet of Everything" market-texture.
cons: Cisco has become more and more about who you know and who likes you, in lieu of what you have delivered or your value-add to the company, shareholders and/or customers. Politics now dominate the landscape and the embedded bureaucracy is only for the strongest of heart.

review_title: Voice Technology Group - avoid at all costs
job_title: Program Manager in Boxborough, MA
pros: They are supportive about flex time and telecommuting. Paychecks arrive as scheduled.
cons:
There is no on-boarding. If you need to know about something, (f.e.; auto-deposit payroll vs. commission checks) you're expected to find it on the poorly-indexed corporate website(s). For somethings you can call HR in California. The phone staff was always friendly & the on-hold times were ok. However, even at ok, altogether it'll make for very long first days.

There is no relocation assistance, so bargain hard for that signing bonus! 

I can only speak from my experiences, but in my opinion - Do not work for this company. Not unless you enjoy being bludgeoned out of your career by small-minded micro-managers. If you have another option, take it. I had options. And I chose Cisco! Dammit.

Forewarned is forearmed.

review_title: Great company but worried about lack of direction
job_title: Corporate Communications Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Great culture, great security, very smart people. It's a high integrity company with high integrity people. Very people-friendly place to work.
cons: Never-ending reorganizations make it extremely difficult to get anything done. Lots of decisions seem to be made based on politics and personal favors, and those decisions don't last. The result is lack of trust w/ the most executive leadership.

review_title: Good place to work but very slow on career path
job_title: Software Engineer III in Bangalore
pros:
*Best part is the flexibility to work. Flexible timings, work from home.
*One of the best infrastructure, good gym.
*Cab facility
*Enough scope to learn
cons:
*You may not get hikes for couple of years in a row
*Very senior people are still waiting for their promo. 
*Depends but chances are you have to take calls sometimes even at late night
*If you are more into customer issues you will be stressed.

review_title: Cisco is losing the fight to attract and retain talent
job_title: Director in San Jose, CA
pros:
(1)  Flexible work environment.  Can work from home
(2)  Salary and benefits are good
(3)  Still has a few good executives and leaders
cons:
(1)  Cisco has been in a state of constant restructuring for the last 4 years.  Roles and responsibilities can change overnight
(2)  Morale of employees is at an all time low.  And most of the management does not seem to care
(3)  Cisco has lost its innovation edge.  Its a company that is slowly going out of business
(4)  Zero career growth opportunities

review_title: Global Marketer
job_title: in Berkeley, CA
pros: Great people with deep experience.  Bench strength was phenomenal -- deep subject matter expertise in a broad array of capabilities.   Mature org that meant it was rare to see a mandate without the resource plan to make it happen -- far different than many tech companies in that regard.
cons: Going through a major re-org throughout most of my time there.  I had three bosses and four roles in less than 18 months.  Profesionally, that was invigorating but it didn't yeild as high a contribution  that a bit more stability would have afforded.

review_title: Great Company... needs to evolve fasters
job_title: Account Manager in London, England
pros:
Great culture, everyone happy to collaborate and help each other. 
Management hierarchy is relatively flat and most managers are very open to conversations and getting stuck in at all levels of the business. 
Packages are competitive, and the commission get's exciting when you star to overachieve.. 
Cisco of course carries a big brand into a lot of accounts so getting in front of customers is never a challenge...
cons: Still a hardware vendor first, massively needs to look at becoming more software driven, and refining the cloud proposition - and fast. Work needs to be done on Cisco's business relevance to IoT, digitization and the move towards applications and software.

review_title: Overall Good Company w/ Flexibility
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Work-life balance, work from home perks, good benefits -- full gym, health center on campus, job stability, free shuttle from SF, growth opportunities
cons:
- A LOT of corporate politics which creates a negative work environment where teams within the same organization are fighting against each other instead of working together 
- Still working in a waterfall/semi-agile
- Not a "tech start-up" feel (limited free snacks, subsidized lunch, gym cost comes from pay check, not very many millenials)
- lack of clear roles and responsibilities

review_title: CSAP: Opportunities are Sky-high
job_title: Systems Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
1) Joined Cisco through one of the industry's best  early-in career program called CSAP (Cisco Sales Associate Program). This extensive  1 year training program includes a 6 month on-the-job experience & prepares us for field role.  This program infact accelerates our career & gets us at par with a 5-8 year experienced Systems Engineer role.

2) The culture of the company itself is to nurture each-other & grow together. So all the colleagues ,  mentors & managers are extremely supportive , guiding us to climb the ladder of our career

3) As a part of technical pre-sales, I get the exposure to both crucial technical design discussions & the business side of the company.
cons: None. Cisco is one of the best companies you can work for.

review_title: It's a double edged sword
job_title: Manufacturing Engineering Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: The best Cisco offers is flexibility in working hours.  Lots of options in when and where to work from.  Home and different locations.  Other benefits aren't the best but are acceptable.
cons: Downside is the flexibility in working hours can sometime end up causing you to work extra long hours especially when under a time crunch.  Cisco has a fully outsourced manufacturing.  As such, many of the manufacturing operation has long since moved to lower cost regions.  This resulted in the need to work odd hours considering that time zone differences.  This can at times be a strain when new products are being launched.

review_title: An ambitious company with its heart in the right place.
job_title: Support in London, England
pros: An ambitious company with its heart in the right place. Capable of producing incredible technology. Pay and conditions are excellent and you get the sense that you work for a company that is not out to screw its employees. Company has a very high reputation that is, in my opinion, well deserved.
cons: Despite working for a networking company, communication between functions can leave a lot to be desired. Company is known for being inflexible towards its customers. The overall strategy and direction can sometimes come across as being a little vague.

review_title: Decent Internship Experience
job_title: Software Engineering Intern in San Jose, CA
pros: Great pay for an internship, great experience if you end up in the right group.  San Jose's a nice area to live for the summer, and the other interns there are good people.
cons:
The learning curve when you join makes most of a three month internship dedicated to figuring out what's going on in the company, although I'm sure this is pretty common across companies this size.

The intern experience can vary greatly depending on what group you end up in, and there's no way to know this before hand.  Some groups will have you doing real work while others won't.

review_title: Cisco did not continue to value human capital as the company grew.
job_title: Many in San Jose, CA
pros: Challenging work which contributes to a lot of learning and growing as an employee and as a person.  Working there twenty years ago when the business was booming, was a fantastic, one time life experience.  There are a lot of smart people at Cisco, which was a great environment to work in.
cons: They lost focus of the most important asset, people.  It is a very top and bottom organization/company.  The executive compensation gap compared to 55% of the company, is HUGE.  There should have been more key leadership changes at the very top, much much much sooner and often.

review_title: They care about employees
job_title: Systems Engineer in Miami, FL
pros: Benefits are good. Cisco works very hard to put excellent people in their roles that collaborate together. In the time that I have been here I have found all my coworkers very helpful; we all work together to make sure we are all successful.
cons:
The money is good but could be better. 
Each year there are management changes which are good and bad. You never know if you will be working for the same manager for more than one year. If you really love your manager you may not have him the next year. 
Fortunately most managers are great people and also try and make you successful at what you do. 
Big challenge with expense control. Sometimes it's limiting to doing your job.

review_title: All in all -- it's a good place to work
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Jose, CA
pros: In my experience bonus + salary is pretty tough to match at competitors.  Great work/family balance, working remotely is generally allowed (but I never tried to abuse it).  In general the work is interesting and furthers my career as a software engineer.
cons: Sometimes I feel as if my work assignments are not as "meaty" as I would like.  At other companies I've had a lot broader scope and responsibility.  It's not always the case; I think it varies from group to group and even manager to manager.  Promotions can be tough to come by (at least for grade 10 and above) and is largely dictated by your level of visibility and playing politics.

review_title: Cisco Systems is a great company to work for. It has great offerings to sell and great colleagues to work with.
job_title: Senior Account Manager in Cape Town
pros: Strong brand with great earnings potential for sales people as Cisco basically can offer customers a solution across a much the wider spectrum compared to other network vendors
cons: Strong focus on sales numbers, so it kind of consumes your life leaving little space for other matters of life. Cisco is 40+ B$ company, but it's share price battles to compete with likes of a 1 B$ ntwk company like Ciena's share price - something is wrong up there?

review_title: Sucks to work for Product Management
job_title: Business Analyst in Milpitas, CA
pros:
-If you are a loud speaker and enjoy talking for hours and doesn't matter if you are talking sense or not, you can climb to the top and do quite well (Director level) with this company.
-Without college degree?  No problem, I've seem people get their foot in the door as a contractor and then kiss their way up.  

-Good medical benefits
cons:
- No more perks like free water, soda, juice, commuter's check ,etc.  
- Free lunch for monthly staff meetings became pot luck.
- Worked 14-16 hours per day.  No overtime pay.
-Too many meetings, and very little time to do any work.

review_title: "Not the Cisco of the past..."
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Chicago, IL
pros:
Good place for younger people and recent college grads to get a start in Networking.
Competitive benefits.
cons:
Cisco has done a reset over the last 4 years, moving their compensation and benefits ranges down to match
new younger employees.  Not a  lot of growth opportunities. Rampant racism and infighting between corporate and India operations.  Lack of senior leadership, vision, direction.  If you just want to get some experience on your resume, work hard and keep your head down, then you'll do ok.  If you want a long term career, go somewhere else.

review_title: Love working at Cisco
job_title: Network Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: I love working in the Technical Services organization at Cisco in RTP, NC.  There is a competitive, yet laid-back atmosphere that I really enjoy.  There are many opportunities for development and coworkers and managers are very supportive and are typically quick to recognize individuals for their good work.  The salary is decent but coupled with all the great benefits the overall compensation package is certainly competitive.
cons: Skilled engineers can make a better base salary at smaller companies in the area although job stability and the benefits are likely the trade-off.  Otherwise I can't think of many cons to working at Cisco.

review_title: Incredible culture and experience
job_title: Practice Advisor in San Jose, CA
pros:
Transparent leadership decision making
The best technology in the world
Fantastic work experience, from offices to how they equip you remotely
Focus on YOU as an employee, not what you do in a current role
High ability to move around, try new things and grow new skills
Every employee has a voice, and it is listened to
Working with the smartest, talented team in the world, around the world
cons: some times the work from anywhere, anytime does encroach on personal life, especially if your team is global.  That said, the expectation is you are responsible for this -  and take time back for yourself another occasion.

review_title: Partner Marketing Manager
job_title: Partner Marketing Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: World class company.  Many Type A employees.  $50B in revenue which makes it tough to grow significantly.  Top compensation packages and benefits.  Many interesting projects on routing and switching, cloud and IoT.
cons: Frequent reorganizations and layoffs.  Most of the business is stilled tied to routing and switching which are slow growing businesses.  Disorganized and Constant budget pressure and the need to do more with less resources.  Lots of hidden headcount with contractors which account for 70K heads.

review_title: Excellent employer
job_title: Software QA Engineer in Shanghai, Shanghai
pros:
* The pay is above the average comparing with other R&D center of similar size foreign companies in China. 
* Unlike most other Chinese companies, overtime work is not common.
* It is a pleasure to work with professional colleagues.
* Managers are supportive.
cons:
* Strict with travel cost. Used collaboration tools heavily to avoid traveling.
* No travel allowance if travel abroad. Just cover all the actual cost of accommodation, dinner and transportation.
* Career opportunity for software QA engineers is not as good as software engineers.

review_title: Good place to work, but lots of politics
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Overall, good opportunities (if you know where to look), ability to impact the industry, solid benefits, great life/work balance and reasonable salaries.  There is a reason Cisco consistently makes "best place to work" lists.  The leadership change has been a huge positive.
cons: The closer you are to the core businesses, the more politics you end up having to deal with--it can be a huge productivity tax. The market is evolving and some leaders are in denial about this, which can be equal parts frustrating and entertaining.  The thing is, Cisco is so big, you cannot make a blanket statement, it really ends up depending on your manager and management chain.

review_title: Great company to work. Excellent benefits.
job_title: Software Engineer II in Bangalore
pros:
Exposure to latest technologies.
Excellent work from home option.
Half yearly bonus.
Recognition in terms of RSU, gift vouchers and much more.
Salary on 25th of every month or last weekday before 25th.
quarterly team outing or lunch.
stock purchase option.
fun activities. Sponsored training.
Medical insurance covers parents as well.
Company transport at a very subsidised rate.
Manager feedback etc
cons:
Be ready to be fired any time. Quarterly results play a vital role.
Cisco is well renowned for networking and firing
Annual appraisal depends on your business unit.
You will get used to hearing headcount reduction, business unit sale or some acquisitions quite often.
Appraisal only single digit.
Performance doesn't matter when it comes to firing.
I feel sad for my fellow Colleagues losing jobs

review_title: For a good work-life balance
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros: I have been working in this company for 10+ years in India Site. I have found that this company adopts best industry standards when it comes to software development process or employee care. It provides you the choice on how you want to contribute yourself. I have seen colleagues who been rightly rewarded with promotions and higher grades when they give exemplary contributions. It pays as you perform without any hindrance. You can choose to grow slow and steady while giving enough time to your family. In other words company allows you to grow as you desire. One another good things is that this company provides good transport service for its employees.
cons: On some areas I feel India site is not having R&D opportunity in latest technologies.

review_title: Cisco Rocks!
job_title: Principal Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Flexible work hours
- Relaxed environment, challenging work
- Awarded for hard work and results
- Great exposure to different technologies
cons:
- Due to company size, lots of free loaders
- Sometimes number of years trumps newer innovative thinking from junior/inexperienced folks
- 80/20 rule applies, company seems to run on 20% of the folks doing a lot more than the 80% who are doing what is expected, nothing more.

review_title: Grab the opportunities to grow
job_title: Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
The best part about Cisco Systems is the diverse portfolio of the company would provide you with immense opportunities to grow. You can be certain of finding a job you like. 

Other Pros include

1. Great Management who provide space to grow.
2. Flexible timings and Work from Home.
3. Work and Play. Time is devoted to both work and enjoyment involving outings and field trips.
4. The company is a market leader in is technology. Once you master it, you become a domain expert.
cons:
1. Some areas need growth in terms of research expenditure.
2. Layoffs is a concern in both senior level and fresher positions.

review_title: Your survival, promotion & bonus depend on the BU you get in - more like matter of luck
job_title: Tech Lead in San Jose, CA
pros:
1. Excellent Benefits & 401K match
2. Flexibility
3. The CEO has been leading a great transition towards Software & subscription revenues and the stock price reflects it.
cons:
* The individual performance only matters to a minimal extent as we keep hearing from our managers and directors over and over again that the BU did not get enough budget for promotions or hikes. So even if you are a high performer and are not in one of those GREAT BUs, the hikes are not really hikes. You can get stuck way below the market range for your grade.

* Not sure if the company / HR has disclosed about gender pay gap.

review_title: If you dreamt about Cisco then think of it as a bad dream
job_title: Software Engineer || in Bangalore
pros:
The perks are good but thats about it. There is a the all famed claim that "Cisco is a big company" but that is all that happens.

From the day you join till end you hear the same dialogue again and again.Everything is an aquired project and no one has a clue about bringing it to ship shape quality.

The cafeteria is even outsourced so to speak and it was the worst caterers ive ever seen in my life. The people raise complains all the time but its of no use.

Occasionally theres a fire drill for which we need to run downstairs , thats one thing i learnt from there
cons:
sick management
lack of vision
no proper management or visionary views
no guidance or mentoring in moulding new employees into anything

review_title: It is a Software job
job_title: Software Engineer I in San Jose, CA
pros: Good for anyone who lives networking, C, Java, and web applications. Pays well and benefits are ok. Work from home is especially good.
cons:
It is a software engineering job and can be very boring and tedious at times. Java is non-algorithmic coding and the only thing you learn is more Java. You don't really research any novel ideas and implement them, just maintain and update old products with new features. Features developed sometimes makes you think if anyone will use it, even internally. If you are not interested in software, this is not your heaven. 

Performance is based on how many customer found defects you resolve and quality of your code.

review_title: Cisco is not a great place to work if you are ambitious
job_title: Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros: If you want to lead a peaceful life with no tensions then cisco is the place for you. I think cisco is a great place for married people as married people need to stike a balance between their married and professional lives.
cons: The downsides are unlimited. Cisco's talent retention policy is pathetic and they dont give adequate recognition to the talent they have. infact in one of the interviews i've heard chambers say that they dont like to hire the best. Cisco is a place for a mediocres. Cisco is the number 1 networking company in the world but from the salaries perspective they are at the 60th percentile.

review_title: Cisco System is a very nice place to work
job_title: Manager, Software Development in Bangalore
pros: It has a very open culture and takes care of it's employees well. Most of the time work ethics and responsibility taken by employees are good
cons: Off late, open culture is going away, by virtue of cisco allowing it's acquired companies to giving a complete free hand and that has destroyed some of the good DNA of Cisco. Most of the time, the head of these acquired companies and it's VPs manipulate things just under the nose of Cisco's heads just for their personal growth and destroy the team and later run away to other companies.

review_title: Enjoyed the caliber of people I worked with and the fast paced work culture within the group
job_title: Principal Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco is truly  caring about employees and when John Chambers calls us the Cisco Family, he really means it. Cisco's  compensation and benefit packages are excellent compared to other industry peers. Cisco has an excellent senior leadership team at the top.
cons: In some areas, Cisco has too many layers of management. Also, the work culture can be quite inconsistent across teams. Some teams would be working many hours and tight deadlines and other groups taking it easy.

review_title: Great Experience just don't stay too long in any one area.
job_title: Customer Support Engineer II in San Jose, CA
pros: Great exposure to technology and corporate culture. Good work/life balance. Decent compensation and great benefits.
cons: If you stay in one role for more than a few years you could end up stuck there. Not to mention things become repetitive very fast so move around in order to stay relevant and continuing to learn. Management is not in sync across the bored so you can be a super star on one team, but a complete failure based on the criteria of another team. This is harmful to those who want to move around in the company.

review_title: Too many chefs...
job_title: Engagement Manager in London, England
pros: Cisco is very good in being accommodating and treats its employees with respect, respects their personal time and tries its best to be flexible.
cons: Hierarchies are quite closed, there is little to no chance to get promoted and there seems to be a never ending number of management levels tripping over each other. Difficult to see accountability. Also since they introduced webex, people don't see eachother anymore and teams don't meet face to face anymore - a loss of humanity in my opinion.

review_title: Great company to learn ..not so great for professional and salary advancement
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Great learning, Market leader, in-depth customer perspective shaping products
cons:
Employees who stay at Cisco are not rewarded..Case in point I got a 40-50% jump in salary when I switched to another competitor. Takes too long to get a promotion. 
Company is very bureaucratic and even small projects having a demonstrable but small impact (in the 10-50 Mln $ range) take a long time to get approval. Company is built around getting massive transitions correctly.

review_title: Software Engineer III
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Really good work-life balance
- You are given time to finish your projects and to experiment , there is no real pressure or stress
- Nice team of people to work with
cons:
- There is a red tape and hierarchy here which makes it difficult to get your projects approved 
- Projects get cancelled and layoffs are high even when customers are excited about your product
- There is a bias during Performance review so you will never get top 10% even if you are superstar and your Director does not think so 
- No innovation (or) thought process around user experience

review_title: technical lead
job_title: Technical Leader in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexibility - people can work remote somewhat, depending on your manager.  However, if people don't see you in the office, people may not know who you are.  When the next localized or global layoff (which is very frequent) comes, you may have the high chance to be on the list.
cons: There are groups at Cisco which are plainly fat.  There primary existences are to justify their own existences by spinning initiatives to make them look good even though there are no meets in those initiatives.

review_title: Slow moving, but opportunities will be found
job_title: Account Manager in London, England
pros:
- Market leading technology, lots of acquisitions too, which make approaching customers with new propositions much easier.
- Great team culture around collaboration, and working together as one unit
-  Work life balance and flexibility to work from home is brilliant and is aided by Cisco's technology.
- Company trying to evolve and capture market transitions - Software, IoT, Cloud which makes for an existing future.
cons:
- Pace of change and execution is awfully slow
- Despite claims of being a software company, sales team is still heavily product orientated. 
- Stale middle management have become "stuck in their ways" and lack new innovative ideas to drive real change.

review_title: View from a current employee
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cary, NC
pros:
Can work from home. 

Management leaves you to do your job for the most part.  

There is a strict unwritten rule not to lose it (aka, yelling at employees, writing rude emails and etc...) no matter how hot the subject .  It will not happen right away but, they will isolate and layoff those people.  A very good culture requirement.
cons:
On call 24/7.  

Things that are normal for a big company aka watching management change direction randomly, people sending pointless emails to the entire company.

You just ignore requirements and endless demands take mandatory training.  

At the end of the day they realize that you are very valuable in the customer's eyes and that is all that matters.

review_title: Great Company
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
Diverse opportunities -supports career moves across functional silos
Competitive compensation and benefits
Good people - little to no tolerance for empire builders and leadership by fear
Collaboration culture - supports flexible working, virtual collaboration, etc
cons:
Big company - takes a while for anyone to connect all the dots.  You will likely find people in different organizations trying to achieve the same goal not knowing about each other
Work hours - global company means working across time zones, partly compensated by flexible working, but if you need a 9-5 job this may not be for you.

review_title: Great when and where you find the freedom to work
job_title: Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Initially after we were acquired, we were hopeful about finally having the stability to continue working on our technology with the resources of a bigger company. Cisco was pretty good about leaving us alone for the first little bit, but the corporation has got to corporate at some point you know.

The benefits were solid, fair and generously doled out on regular schedules. This is a great place to maintain and build with a moderate pace of progress professionally.
cons: Cisco as a company isn't really doing anything innovative, and really feels like a stagnant hardware company trying to pivot into software in many ways.

review_title: Cisco - More like a bank. No real RnD going on.
job_title: Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros: Good package, Good work life balance, good start for fresher's I'm terms of package.
cons: No job security. Employees live in fear of layoffs everyday. No real RnD going. Cisco wants to be huge, but there is no concrete vision. It's more of a bank. Lot of buying and selling. Staying at Cisco for long, could end your career due to lack of challenge. They don't have uniform policies across countries. Biased policies, Indian employees are taken for granted.

review_title: Times are changing, mostly for the better, and quickly
job_title: Senior Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Incredible ongoing focus on people and experiences
Opportunities to help determine direction just keep coming
Executives really want to hear from everyone, not a yes culture
Employees feel more heard and a part of decisions around what's next
Easy to rotate or move into other parts of the business to round out your skills and knowledge
Recognizes the need to evolve constantly and tries to do so
cons:
Sometimes we focus too much on making a change instead of is it the right one to make.  
We don't always backpedal fast when we realize we took the wrong course.  
Experiences are not consistent across the company.

review_title: The Best Place to Work
job_title: Technical Solutions Specialist in Almaty
pros: There are many reasons to love Cisco. I would highlight the three main ones about this company. Firstly, in Cisco you are surrounded by truly talented, knowledgeable, and kind people and you are a part of a big (global) diverse family.  Secondly, each member of this family has great opportunities to grow and develop themselves personally, intellectually, and professionally. And thirdly, Cisco is indeed about honesty, integrity, and transparency, which is very important for me personally and many of us.
cons: This is not really a downside, but a more challenging thing when working in Cisco. It is constant changes that the company goes through because of the constant and rapid changes in the market and industries. This requires you to be agile and adaptive.

review_title: Good place to work, but not great.
job_title: Technical Leader in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexible working hours, challenging work if you are lucky to be in a good project. Also being a big company, there are distinct advantages in getting answers to any questions that you have (technical or non-technical). Makes the most effective use of on-line resources. Has a very good social community.
cons: Salaries are not great. Lots of middle management and program managers. Its very hierarchical, so dont expect to be recognized or rewarded for any good work. Stock never rises, so dont expect to make any money from stock options.

review_title: The kool-aid needs more sugar
job_title: Software Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Executives do a good job of fiscally managing company
Nice Campus with on-site gym, cafeterias, and coffee shop
Free drinks for employees
Relaxed dress code
Flexible work schedule
If you look hard enough you can find some interesting projects to work on.
cons:
No salary increases in the last several years. Entire sites were skipped over even as other sites did get raises.
Overuse of the words "collaboration" and "innovation" by management. Just because the words are spoken, that alone doesn't make it happen.
Large corporate environment, lots of politics, process, and lack of communication.
Lots of jobs heading to India and China.

review_title: Overall a fun place to work
job_title: Business Operations Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Overall a great company. Employees genuinely like their job. There is lots of flexability in terms of when and when you work. With a 60,000 person company, there is also lots of opportunity to move around and try different things. The management also practives what they preach (the Vp's all have small offices and fly coach). They encourage continued education and there is a great selection of classes at 'Cisco University' that you can take to enhance your skill set.
cons: 1% raise pool each year. This does not exactly motivate everyone to excel. The company is also pretty frucal when it comes to travel and stock options.

review_title: Great compensation, good training
job_title: Lead Systems Engineer in Karāchi
pros:
- Very innovative company always coming out with new products and services
- Wide community and people really willing to help out
- Compensation is amazing
- Lots of benefits, like free internet at home, free drinks at offices
- Flexibility, ability to work from home
cons:
- lack of career growth and advancement, you often get stuck with the job position and salary that you started with
- harder to transition into new and more challenging roles
- too sales focused

review_title: Cisco lost its way
job_title: Global Sales Engineer in Atlanta, GA
pros: Fun work environment, flexible work hours and spaces, great customers to work with.  For a long time Cisco had a great strategy and moved into innovative areas, but the economy crashed and Cisco had to refocus.
cons: We ran out of products and our BUs bacame too political and lost their mojo.  They lost all the good people and have been left with subpar PMs and others.   Cisco's had a series of layoffs and has demoralized the company.  Cisco has exited a number of businesses and is more of an R&S company as opposed to a true communications company.

review_title: Good ethics. Decent execution. Poor innovation.
job_title: Senior Manager, Product Management in San Jose, CA
pros: Collaborative, supportive culture. Management typically supports telecommuting and PTO for family emergencies. The company is very responsive to larger enterprise customers.
cons: Execution in this big company can often get confused. Frequently, obvious issues fall through the cracks and result in disappointed customers. Aiming high for innovation is that much more challenging, and the company is still not software-oriented in multiple ways.

review_title: Combination of very engineering driven product development ire strong consultative sales teams.
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Opportunity to work with really smart people and see the impact of your work. Always new projects and work on new approaches. Cisco may not always be first but they are never shy about admitting they need to accelerate efforts to catch-up. For a large company they are quiet nimble.
cons: Large company with very distributed decision making that is hard to make stick. To make big impact there are a lot of internal politics to work through and deal with. The company in general wants to do the right thing but frequently trips over its own feet.

review_title: Out of touch leadership. A lot of speak, no action.
job_title: Business Analyst in San Jose, CA
pros: The hours are great. A lot of flexibility. The salaries are decent, but with the flexibility added in, they become much better than the rest of their competitors.
cons: Slow to act. I had a terrible manager who was around for 5 years too long however, senior leadership would not let him go until layoffs took place. The extra time he spent sticking around led to relationship break downs with stakeholders and talent moving onto other teams due to his poor leadership style. I feel that senior leadership does too little for their employees while they walk away with large salaries and bonuses.

review_title: Tomorrow, doesn't start here only incompetence.
job_title: Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Employees are genreally nice and friendly, great place to start out and learn about the IT industry, decent reputation
cons: Stupid acronyms, over-inflated egos, Managers are AMATEURS, Contractors are treated like third class citizens, tons of bureaucracy.  Values Profits over Employees all day/everyday.

review_title: Review of Cisco Systems from a former employee
job_title: Program Manager in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: Cisco is a great company to work for, I was fortunate enough to spend 15 great years with them.  They provided me with a good severance package and great support when I was laid off.
cons: I missed the "Start Up" feel and mentality that Cisco had when I first started there.  While everyone talks about cross functional work and flexibility the work and hierarchy is still very siloed.

review_title: Shocked at how much I like working at Cisco
job_title: Sales Specialist in Arlington, VA
pros:
I was a small company girl, last year my company was acquired by Cisco, in candor I was very concerned about working at such a large organization. I was pleasantly surprised by how inclusive and supportive the culture was. I have never felt that I had as many opportunities as I do at Cisco.

Of course it is also great to work for a company with as strong a brand as Cisco!

The other thing worth mentioning is that at Cisco our team is so strong that when I went on vacation this summer, I didn't have to work! Being in Sales that is a first for me.
cons: Cisco is huge! That means sometimes the you have to deal with information overload.

review_title: Stay away from this company
job_title: Software Engineer in Glasgow, Scotland
pros: OK work-life balance, remote Work, some really cool people
cons:
Arrogant management, big focus on OPEX , the way company progres is by  running layoffs marathon every 3 months. There is no appreciation , people get fired if they have opinion different than manager and HR covers up all those cases. The leadership has no clue about the products they are asking engineers to build, things  getting build and scrapped and rebuild and to cover the failure its being presented as a learning curve (learning when everyone already knew it?)
The career opportunities do not exist. Pay is rather low compare to the market

There is few great people but the culture coming from the upper management is disgusting, saying you either with us or you should live ... not nery motivating on  convincing.

review_title: great company for Asian, especially for Indian or on H1-visa
job_title: Tech Lead in San Jose, CA
pros:

Friendly environment to H1-visa holders.
Presentation and Talk is more important than building things because we buy instead of build.

Annual layoff.

Too many reorg, sometimes it takes longer to move up.

review_title: Good workplace and competitive compensation
job_title: Senior Software Development Engineer in Bangalore

Friendly co workers

Work pressure is certainly more
Job uncertainty as layoffs LR are frequent

Political senior mgmt level
Growth in terms of compensation or role is stagnant or very slow

review_title: Cisco - an OK company to work for, nothing more, nothing less.
job_title: Software Engineer I in San Jose, CA
pros:
World renowned company, everyone knows the name.
Many extremely intelligent, knowledgeable employees.
Numerous training courses available to further career options both within and outside of Cisco
Brilliant IT infrastructure: Great support, technical resources second to none
Certain benefits: Free drinks, good medical plans, good retirement funding plans
cons:
Salary below industry standards, grading and salary increases are awarded in a staggered manner (promoted first, then payed more "at some stage")
Growing trend towards extreme frugality is becoming bothersome: Benefits are slowly being taken away in various theatres across the globe (Asia Pacific reducing bottle waste - no more juices or bottled water)

review_title: Cisco is a Great Place for Interns.
job_title: Hardware Engineering Intern in San Jose, CA
pros: It has an up and coming internship program that seems focused on attracting new hires.  If you are able to take part in the Cisco choice program you are given a decent level of flexibility in choosing which group you would like to work for.
cons: It is a large company and it seems like it would be hard to advance positions.  I think this is a characteristic of most tech companies though.  I have been told the best way to get a raise or advance is to get a job at another company.

review_title: Best place to work in coporate America.
job_title: Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: There are very good people at Cisco and comitted to customer success.  The senior management is smart and understands the business.  Benefits are good and overall compensation is on par with the industry.  There are different opportunities to learn and grow in different technologies.  Cisco is the leader in shaping the way the world communicates.  It will be a great company for a long time.
cons: Promotion opportunities are limited.  You either have to have been here over 10+ years or have come in at the level you feel you are working at.  Once inside, unless you have a guardian, performance with a combination of ability will not you get you very far.

review_title: Stay away if you have a choice...
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Flexible work schedule depending on your immediate manager -- but if you are expected to work 20 hours -- does it really matter?
It might be possible to use your time spent at Cisco in lieu of course work towards Political Science degrees.
cons:
Not a technology-oriented company.
Not many US educated employees, nor many people with advanced engineering degrees.
Employees are usually Indian with a typical background (Indian education from unknown universities); get on the boat using India Consultancy Inc.; jump ship to Cisco and hang around there for a long time to become part of management -- continue hiring new people off the boat -- build empires and bask in the glory of sycophants.

review_title: Hard working, fun and Competitive.
job_title: in Riyadh
pros: You'll enjoy workplace flexibility, team work, competitiveness, good salaries, travel, diversity and a great high tech learning environment.  Besides you'll make a lot of good friends. review_title: Quite employee friendly. Overall decent work life balance.
job_title: Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros: Exposure to multiple dimensions of Networks. Chance to work and interact with the best in the industry. Definitely a haven for those intrigued by Operating Systems, Computer Networks, and Distributed Systems(the company owns more than 85% of the network deployed in the World).
cons: Doesn't provide competitive salary in the subcontinent region. Moreover, the rate of progress is not very competitive for someone who just works hard and doesn't ask for returns. Overall, you have to make them know about you hard work all the time.

review_title: Good company to learn

review_title: Good exposure and experience to work so closely with the customers production environments.
job_title: Software Engineer II in Chennai

cons: Actually the overall time that you spend in Cisco Systems adds to your professional portfolio and increases the experience of how big multinationals work and deliver solutions to client. Thus sometimes, the project management does not give clear roadmaps on the product.

review_title: A company that excels at the process of on-boarding and off-boarding - it's in-between that falls down
job_title: Team Leader in San Jose, CA
pros:
Chance to work with some very experienced, professionals who have kept Cisco at the forefront.

review_title: Great benefits, good salary, uninspiring work, mediocre management
job_title: IT Engineer in Raleigh, NC

cons: Depending where you get placed, the work may or may not match with your skill set or be of the most interest to you. Changing this can be difficult and must be fought for. Management changes can be frequent (3 in about 16 months) and political which can lead to a feeling of misdirection. Hard work can go unnoticed and so can slacking off

review_title: Decent place to work

review_title: Poor Management, Clueless managers

review_title: You Can Grow, Reinvent Yourself, Create Your Best Ideas

review_title: Customer Success Customer
job_title: Customer Success Manager in Athens, Attica

The opportunities to grow in this company are plenty.  Nice benefits and highly skilled people ready to assist you at any time.
cons: As it is a dynamic environment it needs careful consideration for someone who doesn't like changes. Sometimes the training material and process can be too much in order to be up to speed as fast as possible.

review_title: Great benefits, not the highest payer when starting out
job_title: Customer Support Engineer in Richardson, TX

There is career advancement but it's only one or two steps, and if you're technical you have to go to sales or management.  Support perspective, horrible work/life balance; they tack on a lot of extras in addition to the 10 -12 hour work day that suddenly become required.

review_title: Great company for the motivated, independent worker!
job_title: Applications Consultant / Network Consulting Engineer  in Atlanta, GA

cons: Visibility, disconnection, isolation. Working with so many great people in such a disconnected environment (remote/travelling/telecommuting) presents challenges to gaining visibility. The distributed nature of the job lends to a feeling of disconnection to the chain of command occasionally.

review_title: Workig with the best and brightest in the industry, a blessing and a curse.
job_title: Technical Support Manager in Richardson, TX
pros: employee empowerment. work areas, and employee benefits. cons: Long work hours needed to compete with peers. Tough policy of maintaining the top 10%, their is constant pressure to manage out the bottom 5% performers, as there will always be a bottom 5%, there is constant pressure to stay on top of your game. Cisco sells the company ownership package to argue lower salaries.

review_title: Good for a very long term career (> 20 yrs)
job_title: Software Technical Lead in San Jose, CA

review_title: Cisco Systems - Dissatisfied

review_title: It was a good experience working for Cisco.  The peers are good, yet management has many layers and way too many VPs.

review_title: Amazingly fast and fun but not grueling

review_title: My overall experience was good.  I enjoyed the people and was afforded to do some amazing things at Cisco.

review_title: i'm humbled to work with such smart people with a supporting attitude

review_title: Great work/life balance, flexi-time, remote working. Competitive salary but slow to progress up the ladder.

review_title: Best 13 years of my career....so far! :-)

review_title: Fast growing department

review_title: Reflections having left

pros:

review_title: Too much uncertainty...very frequent LR

many different opportunities.

review_title: Wonderful place to work
job_title: Corporate Counsel in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco is such a great place to work--the senior management emphasizes integrity and productivity.  For a company of its size, politics are not such a big issue.  Cisco is a great place to work remotely too.  Benefits and career opportunities are good and compensation is roughly in the mid to high range compared to other comparable companies.

review_title: Great place to work for the most part
job_title: Sales in Research Triangle Park, NC

cons: Getting to big, lots of dead weight, could fire 5000 people and wouldnt skip a beat. Too many people making a career at Cisco out of making a career at Cisco. Too many products that overlap and internal competition between different product groups is very counter productive and does not benefit Cisco or the customer.

review_title: Cisco is a great place to work
job_title: Business Analyst in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexible work environment and good benefits. This company is changing the world! There are many opportunities and ways to contribute to the success of this company. review_title: Cisco System's ASR Program: High School from Hell
job_title: Associate Sales Representative in Raleigh, NC
pros: The Associate Sales Representative program is a training program that ultimately feeds into Cisco System's sales force.  You are trained thoroughly for about 8 month.  Subjects of training include everything from how to be a more confident public speaker, to cold calling, to the obvious training on all of Cisco System's hardware and proprietary software.  You are divided into 'teams' within the ASR program and you do most everything during the work day with them.  You have a manager that is your 'team leader' and you have a tech manager who is responsible for teaching you the material on Cisco hardware as well as pointing out the relative strengths and weaknesses similar competitive products have.  The ideal end result of this program is to take a sales oriented person and tech him or her enough technical information so that this person could sit down in a meeting with a client and speak to a CEO, CFO, CTO and answer all of their questions with the caveat that really technical things will be covered by an Associate Sales Engineer (ASE) who is your more technically savvy counterpart.  Cisco's aim is to have ASRs and ASEs work as a team together.  This doesnt exactly work out because the ASR to ASE ration is conservatively skewed at 2 to 1 respectively.
cons:
I was a part of the Associate Sales Representative program, we are referred to as ASRs within Cisco Systems.  The problem working at Cisco is not the upper management or the training; I was very satisfied with those aspects of the job.  Your co-workers will make this a miserable experience.  The dynamics of the training program were worse than high-school.  We were provided with subsidized housing through Cisco and college graduates could not act appropriately.  Some were even kicked out of their leases.  

There were people skinny dipping in the apartment complex's pools, people egging other people's vehicles.  It is the farthest thing from a professional behavior you can imagine.

The sales staff of Cisco Systems is notoriously cocky and if you speak to anyone on the outside who deals with them on any sort of regular basis, they can confirm this.  The program is also set up like indentured servitude.  By which I mean, once you have completed the training program you are bound to work for them at a location of their choosing (ultimately it depends on your desirability as a Sales Representative and suitability to the area) for no less than 2 years.  If you quit before this period, you are required in your contract to pay them back a subsidized portion of your training.

review_title: An ok company
job_title: Software Engineer in Galway
pros:
- Work from home policy is very flexible
- Possibility to take leaves on a very short notice 
- Option available to buy more leaves 
- Any equipment that is needed for work can be ordered without any scrutiny.
- Convenient location if driving from eastern part of county.
- Work/life balance is acceptable. There is almost never any pressure to stay beyond normal working hours.
- Great involvement in local community projects and charity organizations.
- People are genuinely very nice and fun to work with.
- Sports and Social club does a good job organising events throughout the year; there is however a membership fee to participate.
- On top of the above there is a separate fund to organize team outings every quarter which are always good fun.
- A lot of attention is given to constantly monitor and improve coffee machines.
cons:
- Strange location for an IT company, in the middle of an industrial park, outside of town. Not a very pleasant place to go for a walk with trucks and forklifts roaming around. Oranmore village is at least 20 min walk away, which is a bit far if one wants to go out for lunch. That's also where the bus stop is, so it's something to consider if using public transport to get to work.

 - Canteen is very bad. The catering staff are trying their best, but are very limited with what they can do because the kitchen is very badly fitted out, so they can’t prepare any half decent meals.

- Cisco is ultimately a sales, not an engineering company so while good engineering practises are appreciated by some, it’s not what necessarily gets people promoted.

- Salary, promotions and opportunities are good if one knows how to play the game and gets noticed by the right people.

- A somewhat weird/cringy ‘we are an amazing company’ attitude from some people. It’s disheartening how much self-affirmation we received from winning the somewhat irrelevant ‘Great Place to Work’ survey last year while conveniently forgetting that we were competing against some small insignificant companies. We are unlikely to stand a chance if the top US software companies (i.e. companies we should really be compared with) decided to participate in a survey like that. There was a time when they decided to start giving us a free bowl of fruit every day, which is a great initiative if it wasn't sold to us as the greatest thing ever i.e. on the same level of getting a free house.

- Because we don't really having any real proper competition in Galway, the company gets settled in the virtual security offered by ‘we are good enough for Galway’ mindset that hinders any effort or initiative to continuously improve and yet wonders why it is so difficult to attract experienced people in the field to work here.

review_title: Collaboration Group at Cisco has a lot of dysfunction
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
IMPORTANT - Different divisions within Cisco are vastly different from one another, my advice is to make sure you know if a GlassDoor review is relevant to the job that you are applying to.

I work in the Collaboration Technology Group (CTG) which includes WebEx, TelePresence, IP Phones, Jabber and Spark (aka Project Squared).

The Pro's of CTG are:

(1)  Typically your co-workers are great people. My immediate team, for example, is one of the top group of peers I've had in my whole career. They are smart, qualified and everyone cares about each other

(2) The Collaboration Group has some really interesting products, there is a very good chance you'll work on something that is relevant and that you'll be proud to have on your resume 

(3) Cisco offers great benefits. I can almost guarantee you won't find a company that can beat what you get for being a full time employee (Medical, flexible work, 401k matching, etc)
cons:
The con's of working within the Collaboration Group:

(1) At the VP and Director level Cisco is competitive and tumultuous, more so than any company where I've worked in 20+ years. In the last 5 years there have been 4 different Senior Vice Presidents and with each change there has been a lot of churn and changing of priorities.

(2) There is a ton of in-fighting between groups (aka BUs or business units). Basically every Director and VP is incented to compete against ever other Director and VP for budget, resources, attention from executives & the sales force, etc). While this sounds normal for a large corporation, the stakes are high. Winners build set their own agedas and losers can not control their own products and often are subject to yearly layoffs. The bottom line is almost none of the teams are rowing in the same direction, rather everyone competes against each other. 

(3) Most importantly Cisco has a yearly layoff. Every July/August for the last 6 years the company lays off a large number of people. In that time the company has laid off more than 20,000 people and yet the number of employees is larger than ever.  I've seen entire product teams get cut when other teams could sorely use the talented people that were let go. I know someone who got an Outstanding yearly review (which is only given to 6% of people at Cisco), and he was laid-off just a week later. 

Normally you think of a large company as being more stable than a small one, but Cisco is not at all stable

(4) It's very hard at all levels to move up at Cisco. If you are a manager who wants to become a director it's very difficult, the best way to be a director at Cisco is to be at a company that Cisco buys. If you are a Tech Lead who wants to become a Senior Tech Lead the competition is fierce - I know several engineers that have been trying for years to make the next step.

Promotion of the best looking and non-team playing members.  Not really free to take risks, fail and learn.  Lots of bureaucracy, red tape, and processes slowing down decisions, etc. Lot more, "Tried and true, vs. innovate and new".

review_title: Systems Engineering Manager
job_title: Systems Engineering Manager in Melbourne
pros: Workplace flexibility, hands-off management, company culture, volunteering opportunities, complex & challenging opportunities.
cons: Lay-off culture, too many reorgs, Business Units creating overlapping/competing solutions under the same domain, Work life balance, promotions are based on social ladder instead of contribution ladder

review_title: Great environment, but poor management.
job_title: Software Engineer II in Burlington, MA
pros: Being part of Cisco means having an essentially unlimited budget. It's nice that the company provides use with the tools we need to do our job. The culture is wonderful and the benefits are better then average.
cons: Management is generally incompetent. There is a culture of demoing non-existent products, and selling things that have not be done. John Chambers is famous for only doing Flash demos, not real products. Upper management loves to issue press releases about bold visions, but then doesn't follow through with the manpower or time needed to build a good product.

review_title: Cisco!!
job_title: Test Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Stable company.Look at optimizing product groups with clearer decision-making and better integration of product management and engineering. At the end of the day, product groups (incl marketing and engineering) are still 20-70 people, very manageable units. You don't have to concede product development to competitors. Too much compromise
cons:
compensation and career advancement. Only lateral movement moving from one group to the other, absolutely ridiculous policy. 
there should be really an incentive for people to move from one position to the other. 
I did an prestigious MBA program, then when I finish, there is absolutely no upside to move within Cisco. The HR did not find an easy way for me to find a new and exciting opportunity. So I left.

review_title: Cisco - a world of its own
job_title: IT Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Such a big company that you can re-invent yourself every few years if you choose.  Internal transfers are encouraged and learning on the job is highly encouraged.  Most VP's support education and Cisco paid for my MBA.  Cisco has diversified away from core routing and switching, ensuring that we are not at the mercy of the cyclical health of individual market segments.
cons: We have grown so large that promotions have become extremely hard to get.  What used to be an 18-24 month promotion cycle is now about 36-48 months, at best.

review_title: A stellar company with strong leadership and innovation.
job_title: Engagement Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Great company, good leadership, very good benefits, people take pride in their work and actually help each other succeed.  Little pettiness, very professional organziation and community--coworkers are actually friends.  Salaries are very good.
cons: Very little downsides.  High expectations, as this is a very high performing organziation.  But that is to be expected.  There is nowhere to "hide" at Cisco.  If that's what you want or you don't have a good work ethic, look elsewhere.

review_title: Cisco
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco is a decent company that cares about its employees and is a very relaxed enviroment. A good portion of the people get to work after 10 and leave around 4 with a long lunch break and are able to do to the work efficiently.
cons: The experience seems to vary greatly between teams. Avoid the Java folks and you'll be fine ;) They are trying a little to hard to make sure "the sun never sets on Cisco software development" and it creates communication problems for many of the teams. A lot of the employees just slip by but its like that everywhere.

review_title: great place to work if you like anonymity
job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco really supports work-life balance and has many programs for new hires to integrate into the company and socialize with coworkers.  Groups are generally small yielding good sized teams, effective in getting stuff done.  Benefits package is great as well.  Management communicates to employees well (but doesn't necessarily receive employee feedback very well)
cons: A lot of bureaucracy so its hard to get stuff done, especially with technology that functions across multiple platforms.  Sometimes have to work long hours especially close to deadlines.  The company is huge so you really only work with and get to know a small group of people.

review_title: Missing the mark
job_title: Product Manager in San Jose, CA

Inability to innovate.  
Teams spread all over the place; takes twice as long to get stuff done because you have to ping pong protos/equipment/information.

review_title: Cisco,  very top heavy
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Jose, CA
pros: Financially stable company.  For the most part work environment is flexible.  CEO is dynamic.  4 weeks vacation is great.  Well run company.

review_title: A Great Start
job_title: Hardware Test Engineer (Co-op) in San Jose, CA

review_title: very political and difficult place to work
job_title: Video Production Manager in Milpitas, CA

review_title: Not what it used to be...
job_title: Account Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Was a great company with attentive/customer-focused managers that promoted according to merit.  Products are good.  Benefits are great.  Pay is competitive.  Work/Life balance is adequate.
cons: The sales organization is choked with administrative tasks that each new manager creates because they think that a "new" way to collect/collate the same information will yield different results.  The true definition of insanity.  The overlay salesforce has no other capability than to troll those same tools for reasons to ask the same inane questions.  The organization is so choked with useless mid to low level management/overlay organizations that spend more time managing internal expectations rather than customer attentiveness.

review_title: Overall a Nice Place to Work
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Chicago, IL

Great people who are smart and hardworking
Company allows maximum flexibility for work/life balance
Great benefits
Chance for great bonuses

Pays lower than industry standard
Management structure is not conducive to work processes
Slow moving company that sucks at change
Always seems to be a step behind in the industry trends

review_title: Opportunities to learn, grow and establish a career
job_title: Senior Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Ability to work remote was great.  Access to training, tools & technology are there for you to develop your skills.  There are a lot of very talented people for you to work with and learn from.  When you work with the best it will push you to be better.
cons: Working remotely can be a double edged sword.  It does not give you the face to face interaction that is key for building strong relationships.

review_title: Best times are gone, but still a good company to work for
job_title: Director in London, England
pros:
The old days when stock options could make you rich are gone forever, but total package is still good, in the top 50% percentile of similar ICT companies. You can get RSU (restricted stock units) as a bonus each year.
Networking is not as "hot" as it used to be 20 years ago, but it  is still an interesting area for working, in terms of innovation and market opportunities.
Work environment is OK, similar to other large ICT companies, not heaven and not hell, but still  way better than a steel factory, although not as exciting as a startup or high tech software company.
cons:
Morale not great  after many rounds of layoffs.  The company needs a major shift to survive long term, which might be a threat or a great opportunity, depending on where you end up.  Cisco was the Google of the 90s, now it looks more like IBM in the 90s. It is not an innovation leader anymore and market dominance is at risk.
Many senior leaders are focused on politics and protecting their back, so the work environment is not as friendly and relaxed as it used to be. Some of the executives lack the vision, depth and personality. They can manage the "blah blah" in videos, but they fall short when it comes to real market understanding, technology vision  and execution.

review_title: getting worse and bad....

no scope for growth if you are hard working....political pressure to share your work with some favourable workers...

review_title: Technical Lead

review_title: Cisco

review_title: Coin-operated machine : Short term focus

review_title: Good early in career opportunity

Site is amazing and very work-friendly.
Possibility to work from home.
cons:
Unfortunately, many people decide to leave after 2-3 years as there are not enough promotions and salary increases. These is an obvious stagnation for the more experienced employees. 
It seems that the management is more eager to bring new talent than to keep the current one.

review_title: Excellent Company All-around - Especially for Vets
job_title: Service Delivery Executive in San Diego, CA

At Cisco, we recognize the value veterans bring to
the workplace—including a unique set of skills that are
innate in those who have served. Mission-focused.
Leadership. Collaboration. The possibilities for veterans
in technology careers are greater than ever before.

a rewarding career in technology by providing access
to both learning opportunities as well as connections to
our partner ecosystem.
cons: Sometimes promotions can be hard to come by if you stay in one job. But if you are willing to take on new challenges and maybe even relocate, the the opportunities are there.

review_title: Cisco changing the way we work, live play and learn.

cons: Its not a 9-5 job because it is a global company. But work time is flexible.

review_title: Great team and culture - but depends largely on team or organization

Overall would highly recommend working at Cisco to anyone. Oh and amazing work life balance
cons: Always some politics to deal with and things can be slower than you like.  But good culture definitely depends on your leadership and the organization you're in - lay offs do happen frequently at Cisco

review_title: Cisco is both sweet and sour.
job_title: Hardware Engineer IV in San Jose, CA

review_title: Great for fresh graduate with a family

review_title: OK place to work to start out.

cons: San Jose is a very expensive place to live and even though they pay well it seems like it is not enough sometimes.  It is a big corporation, so it can be difficult to earn personal recognition or advance the ladder.

review_title: Good technology but management needs to be straightened out

review_title: CALO Internship/Co-op
job_title: CALO Co-op in Research Triangle Park, NC
