Executive leadership is second to none.
cons: Because many (not all) employees can work remotely, it's difficult to connect to coworkers. While it's great to have the flexibility, we have to work harder at establishing and maintaining a unified sense of commitment.

review_title: Great company to learn and grow as a fresh college graduate.
job_title: Customer Support Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
-Great training and education resources provided. 
-Competitive salary
-Great company culture

It depends a lot on the team you land, but the culture is great. We go out on team dinner very frequently. Even though the company is huge, at some moments, it feels like you are part of a startup within your team.
cons: Because the company is based out in Silicon Valley, they have a lot of competition when it comes to employee perks. For example, we do not get daily free breakfast/lunch/dinner, but it's something you can live without.

review_title: A wolf in a lamb's skin
job_title: Technical Consulting Engineer in Kraków
pros:
This is a wonderful place to boost your experience - it might be technical or non-technical. In all cases you will find something for you. When it comes to carrier boosting - it depends. Cisco is a company of "visibilities" and "egoism" - if you do the right things, you will get your promotion, otherwise you will "die" in humble circumstances and nobody will sorrow about it.

If you are a student, less than 30 years old, have no family, you have a passion for technology so strong, that you are ready to work overtime (of course for free) - this place is right for you.
cons:
Here "good job", "fantastic results", "keep up" phrases mean nothing, at least for management. Cisco is a cruel and bloody business machine. You can rag to riches to rag in few months if you do or don't do the right things. You may work very well, receiving glorious feedbacks from Customers - all it is taken for granted.

You will not see promotion unless you make something really fabulous, thus you will be noticed by Top Management - for example you will visit CiscoLive with your own presentation. Practically it is an easy and very dainty way for Tech Leads, since they are not expected to work "on shift" all the day long. Tech Leads of course supposed to have other responsibilities being an escalation, but who cares that they don't - management adopted a laissez-faire attitude long time ago. As a result bum engineers trample over each other just to get to TechLead paradise.

All above is about Cisco TAC/HTTS and at the end of the day it is my personal opinion only.

review_title: Fantastic company to work for!

I would also like to mention that Cisco have been fantastic throughout Covid-19, they have been understanding and respectful of each individuals situation. review_title: Amazing company

review_title: This company bends over backwards to ensure employee happiness and work/life balance.

review_title: Cisco is a great place to work.  It has changed my life.

review_title: Great collaboration, flexible work options

review_title: Depends on the team and product

review_title: Good place to work

review_title: Partner Account Manager

review_title: Good not great
job_title: Pam in Raleigh, NC

cons: The culture is at a all time low. Local leadership is RTP is horrible. The South Channel OD treats people poorly and talks down to people. It's a toxic environment. Cisco continues to layoff which makes it hard to stay committed to the job not knowing if you will have one.

review_title: Constant Re-org
job_title: Senior Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco is a great technology company and moves fast through acquisition. While that is good for business its not that great for employees, especially those who have worked there for a while. Every acquisition comes with a re-org. Plus there is constant churn at the VP/SVP level.
cons: Un-due stress created for employees through constant re-org and resulting job cuts. Even in profitable businesses. Part of working for a company is a sense of trust that it has your back. In Cisco, its very clear to most employees that they cannot trust the company to take care of them. The next acquisition might take them out.

review_title: Flex time @ Cisxco
job_title: Business Development Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Over the past 5 years, I have been working with a team on the East coast.   I would start my day at 5:30 am in my remote office and be able to stop by 4 pm to start my second job as a Mom.  This is very convenient and allows me to stay very involved with my child's school.
cons: Cisco does have a policy of limiting restructuring every 6 months.  If your department is no longer deems worthy you find whole departments cut.

review_title: Depends on the Team, but mostly good work-life balance
job_title: IT Engineer, Senior in San Jose, CA
pros: Work-life balance is generally good with Cisco IT. Mainly, you can choose to hold back for one year and then next year try to rise above the current gradelevel. Depending on the team, and boss, sometimes, things change. But mostly you can reach out to the skip-level manager and get out of the issues
cons: Cisco is a Networking company - not just the hardware, even soft skill side. They expect people to work with each other. Need to work on soft skills.
